name: Gringgo: Investing in garbage to clean oceans
remarks: Indonesia based foundation, Gringgo is a data driven trash tech startup that's works towards making smarter waste collection: a service that is more reliable, cheaper and greener and also creates more jobs and higher incomes for waste workers. More than 10,000 tons of plastics are used every day in Indonesia. 50% of Indonesians don't have waste collection so dumping into rivers is all too common. Plastic ends up in their oceans and now they are the no. 2 marine plastic polluter in the world.Gringgo initially started as CashForTrash in late 2014. Founded by a team gathered during Startup Weekend Bali 2014 at HUBUD co-working space. It was initially created as a platform for recycling aimed at local schools to make recycling easier, rewarding and fun. The concept has evolved and is now called Gringgo. Once the customers/investors buy garbage, Ginggo harvests the recyclables and sells them to factories and processors for recycling. They then share the profits with the customers/investors.People living in Bali can see on a wastemap all the locations where they can drop their recyclable waste.Users can check through Gringgo's website the list of recyclable items and the current prices. Gringgo also provides through its app a tool for residents to submit pollution complaints and issues such as illegal dumping and open burning of waste. The foundation currently handles over 340 metric tons/month of garbage and have improved recycling rates to over 35%. Their aim is to recycle over 60% of the garbage they collect and expand to other villages across Bali over the coming months.

name: Ichthion: Technology to remove plastic and synthetic waste from oceans
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Ichthion (previously Remora Marine) develops a cutting-edge technology to restore the ocean environment by removing plastics and synthetic waste, before they travel through the entire ocean ecosystem.Microplastics in the sea are a growing threat to human health. Almost 8 million tonnes of plastic waste enter the oceans per year, according to the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, with an exponential increase predicted over the coming years. This is a problem of unfathomable scale with far-reaching effects for wildlife and for humanity, one that makes the future of the oceans seem bleak.Born out of the laboratories of Imperial College London and the studios of the Royal College of Art, Ichthion was created with the sole purpose of restoring the ocean environment. It utilizes the latest technology and research along with a self-critical approach to innovation to ensure its solution remains effective without compromise.They have developed three types of technology streams: Azure, Cobalt and Ultramarine. These operate in different environments to prevent macro and micro plastics entering into the phytoplankton growth areas in coastal zones, and also for the reclamation of plastics in the ocean. Their systems are in Technology Readiness Level 3 (Proof of concept). The potential of their energy-generative systems to tackle the global problem of plastic pollution has been recognized by several prominent organizations through several awards and grants. For example, the Scalable Business Award by Imperial College London, two grants from Climate-KIC, the EU's main climate innovation initiative, the Hawley Award from the Worshipful Company of Engineers. They won the Plastics innovation competition: towards zero waste of Innovate UK.As attempts to clean up the oceans are often highlighted as being cost prohibitive and unlikely to succeed based on scaling factors, Ichthion adopts the same strategy as the eponymous fish. It will circumvent both of these issues simultaneously by using existing infrastructures and adding the technology into them. This gives the necessary scale, avoids huge start up costs, and overlaps coverage with the ecologically important coastal zones.

name: Microplastic-sensing Drone
remarks: As a not-for-profit engineering innovation company, Draper provides unbiased assessments of technology or systems designed or recommended by other organizations — whether custom-designed or commercial-off-the-shelf.Microplastics in the oceans waterways are an ever-growing invisible threat, one that is increasingly becoming part of our everyday lives. This led them to team up with the EPA to combat one of the biggest problems in the world: microplastic contamination. The Mircoplastics-Sensing Autonomous Underwater Vehicle is the first-in-class for microplastic sensing drones. Drapers AUV can detect and analyze invisible microplastics, and enable scientists to understand where they are originating from, where they are most prominent and how to prevent them from contaminating our waters. When the AUV is deployed, it skims the top nine meters of the water where most microplastics are located, scanning for microplastics, testing for specific types, and ultimately relaying GPS coordinates into a heat map.They did this by creating the worlds first real-time microplastic-sensing system in the form of a full-size autonomous underwater drone. The drone will search, find, and analyze this invisible threat to the worlds oceans, coastal regions, and rivers. This will also enable scientists to understand where microplastics originate from and how to prevent them from contaminating our waters.Draper hopes to launch a Plastic Particle Pollution Index posting measurements and trend predictions of microplastic particle concentrations in the worlds oceans, coastal regions and rivers. Draper also plans to make its microplastic sensing technology widely available via open-sourcing so other can contribute to the ppp index.The project is also part of larger long-term strategic design initiative to develop an iconic visual brand language across Drapers different divisions and product categories.

name: Nordsense: A complete end to end solution that optimizes waste collection processes
remarks: A complete end to end solution that optimizes waste collection processes. Nordsense provides a complete end to end solution that optimizes waste collection processes by monitoring container levels, applying advanced data analytics and reducing waste collection trips. It uses cloud-based solutions and artificial intelligence to enable turn-by-turn navigation for waste collection. This eliminates stopping at half empty containers.The solutions it offers are:NS Pod: a small device that can be used with any container or bin. Its novel feature is that it can estimate levels also of plastic bags.NS Platform: It is possible to login to this platform from any device. It provides real time information on bins needing collection. So collection trips and even placement of bins can be optimized so overfull bins are a thing of the past.NS Navigator: This is a mobile application for drivers on collection duties. It lets them know when they have to work, and besides showing the optimal route, it provides directions on which container to stop at. Since information is added in real time, the whole process is dynamic and event driven, and additional full bins can easily be added in the route. It also provides important analytics such as trip duration and cost estimation.The result is that collection trips are minimized,fuel is saved, and trash is collected before containers are overflowing, which leads to illegal dumping. Moreover, congestion on roads by these larger haulers is avoided as well.Nordsense is based in Copenhagen and was started in 2016. Besides working in Copenhagen, they also provide services at San Francisco Public Works. Søren Christensen is the founder and CEO at Nordsense Inc. The company has been covered heavily in Swedish press.

name: Orca Sound Project: Empowering eco-innovation to save our oceans through sense based experiences and collaboration
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Orca Sound Project is a creative platform for sense based experiences and collaborations to raise awareness of our oceans. About 8 million metric tonnes of plastic is dumped in the oceans each year. At the current rate, it is estimated that there will be more plastic than fish in our oceans by 2050. To top it off, only 9% of plastic waste is recycled globally. Orca Sound Project aims to contribute towards reducing the plastic waste present in oceans through creative collaborations and innovations. The organization partners with numerous sound artists and music festival organizers to arrange an event centered around sustainability and ocean conservations. This includes arranging ocean cleanups and ensuring the elimination of single-use plastics.  Orca Sound Project also upcycles the collected wastes into useful products like Orcaboard. Orcaboard is plywood manufactured from 100% mixed waste plastic. Each Orcaboard requires about 30 kg plastic waste sourced directly from the ocean or from the land. The resulting material is sturdy, waterproof and easily washable, making it ideal for temporary use in constructions for events and festivals.In collaboration with Keep Britain Tidy and Shangri-La Glastonbury, they developed the project to build the Glastonbury Music Festival Arena completely from recycled plastic. Waste collection for the project took place between May 11 and May 23, 2019, and an approximate 10 tonnes of plastic was used and processed by Exeter City Council before being recycled into materials to build the stage.The organization also supports global fisheries encouraging them to pick up waste from the oceans in an effort to reduce plastic pollution and combat overfishing.

name: Recykal: Digital technology platform powering marketplace, cloud applications for waste management
remarks: Recykal is a digital technology company powering a marketplace and providing SaaS solutions for the waste management and recycling industries.Recykals technology connects waste generators (businesses, consumers), waste processors (aggregators, informal sector), and recyclers to enable transactions between them bringing transparency and traceability to the ecosystem. Recykal enables FMCGs and electronics brands to run their consumer awareness and takeback programs while complying with the Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) rules outlined by their governments.Their technology, data, and reporting solutions help governments, policymakers, organizations, and communities adopt sustainable practices while creating social, economic, and environmental impact at scale.Recykal has won accolades from industry bodies for its work in the waste management, recycling sectorWinner Emerge 50 Awards 2019 by NASSCOM. Recognized among Most Innovative Software Product Companies in IndiaIndian Circular Economy Awards 2019 (Startup) by FICCIBest Waste Management Digital Technology Provider 2019 by ASSOCHAMEnvironmental Innovation of the Year award at Ecothon 2019 a national level conference on Solutions for SustainabilityWith 5 regional offices, Recykal is currently operational in 25+ states and union territories across India. Their digital footprint, which includes mobile and web apps, has attracted 500,000 users including consumers, bulk waste generators, aggregators, recyclers and the informal sector.Recykal works with 100+ brands in providing various technology products and services pertaining to the waste management space. The Recykal Marketplace application is being used by 1000+businesses and 150+ recyclers in India while the consumer app has been downloaded by 400,000+ individual users. They are working with 70+ FMCG and electronic companies for their technology enabled EPR fulfillment programs.  Recykal partners with global organizations like Unilever, Dow Chemicals, Panasonic, Johnson & Johnson, Pepsi Co, UNDP, Amul, Marico, Pidilite, Godrej, and more on various circular economy initiatives.

name: # tide ocean material: A global supply chain for 100% upcycled ocean bound plastic waste
remarks: Tide Ocean Material transforms the plastics threatening our oceans into new sustainable products. Through it's global supply chain it provides eco-conscious brand with a sustainable premium raw material made from 100% ocean bound plastic. Thus, helping to close the circle of plastic consumption and showing that waste has value.Together with social enterprises, they are collecting ocean-bound plastic in Southeast Asia, coordinated by a #tide subsidiary in Ranong, Thailand. On five islands in the Andaman Sea, local fishermen are being trained and paid to gather and sort plastic waste. The material is registered, washed and shredded in a social enterprise which is being implemented by the Swiss non-profit Jan & Oscar Foundation and the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).   They collect PET, polypropylene, and polyethylene. With Swiss precision, know-how and with the help of clean solar energy, the plastic waste is upcycled into a versatile granular material. The award-winning method was developed in close partnership with the University of Applied Sciences in Switzerland. It is a strictly mechanical process, no chemicals are being added and no virgin plastic is processed whatsoever. The #tide granules are used for plastic injection for watches, furniture, electronic devices, automotive parts and any type of hard plastic product. The #tide yarn can be used for any high quality polyester textile, such as apparel, bags, shoes, home & office interiors. #tide filament can be used for 3D-printing.

name: 4Ocean Technologies: Utilizing the latest forms of technologies to combat the ocean plastic crisis
remarks: Founded in 2017, 4ocean is a purpose-driven business that aims to clean the worlds ocean and coastlines while working to stop the inflow of plastic by changing consumption habits. They are not a nonprofit, and believe in creating sustainable business solutions to achieve their goals.The 2 founders Alex and Andrew launched the company by creating a handmade bracelet and promising to pull a pound of trash for every bracelet they sold. With the money raised from the sales of these bracelets, they have been able to employ hundreds of people to clean the ocean full-time and pull over 5 million pounds of trash from the ocean and coastlines. Beyond their products, they combat the ocean plastic pollution through technology, cleanups, influence, and education. They are developing and testing several types of skimmers:4ocean Mobile Skimmer recovers marine debris from any waterway using this fuel-efficient vessel. Its articulating arms on the front guide marine debris onto a conveyor belt that leads to a super sack with the capacity to hold up to 220 pounds of debris. Measuring slightly over 22 feet long, the 4Ocean Mobile Skimmer team hopes to be a game-changer for cleaning the worlds oceans. The skimmers require just a few people to run it, and they think they will be able to collect much more plastic in much less time than with other methods.4Ocean Solar Skimmer: this semi-autonomous marine debris collector for river mouths and waterways can be situated on a stationary pontoon platform. It uses water inflow to collect marine debris. Trash is transferred from the waters surface to a 6-yard dumpster by conveyor belt. Full receptacles can be serviced and replaced by a one-man tender barge and transported to a municipal offload site.4Ocean Harbour Skimmer is a shore-powered water pump that collects marine debris in harbours and marinas. The fully automatic floating skimmer can be secured to a dock or pier and connected to shore power to remove debris that accumulates in marinas. Three-hundred gallons of water are pulled into the skimmer every minute and up to 1,200 pounds of marine debris can be collected in the units waste receptacle. One push of a button brings the mesh basket to dock level where debris can be unloaded. The Surface Skimmer runs on a standard 110-volt outlet and is a cost-effective way to keep your harbour or marina free of plastic and other debris.The 4Ocean mobile skimmer is currently been tested locally in Florida and the team is planning to deploy several of them internationally.

name: Bandalong Litter Trap: Proven solution for floatables control
remarks: Description: The Bandalong Litter Traps and StormX Netting Trash Traps are passive capturing systems that require no energy other than the natural current or flow.  The Bandalong is used in creeks, rivers, canals, or channel waterways to capture floating litter and debris and DOES NOT harm aquatic species or wildlife. StormX is an end-of -pipe netting systems that can be used on pipe out falls, structures, and in channels to capture both floatables and non-floatables. StormX is not used in live streams where aquatic species and wildlife are present.Both products are proven internationally for over 20 years!Plastic recovery capacity: The BANDALONG LITTER TRAP will capture floating litter and debris 24/7 without mechanical assistance. It has unlimited capacity to capture floatables using our unique boom configuration with the trap without restriction of flow or harm to aquatic species or wildlife. Examples: Washington, DC first litter small Bandalong trap captured 6 tons the first year.  A large Bandalong in Mobile, AL 500 cubic yards the first year.NOTE: WITH THE UNIQUE DESIGN OF THE BANDALONG THE AMOUNTS COLLECTED DEPENDS ON THE AMOUNT OF TRASH FLOWING IN THE WATER THE CAPACITY IS UNLIMITED.STORMX capacity depends on the diameter of the  out flow pipe and the length of the net. All StormX installations need consideration for overflow/bypass options when nets are full of trash and debris.

name: Bantam Ocean Bound Plastic: Providing traceability for products from certified ocean bound plastic
remarks: Bantam Materials International in collaboration with Oceancycle has developed a tracking system for products manufactured using certified ocean-bound plastic materials.Oceancycle provides certification for materials at bottle aggregation sites, in at-risk ocean environments, to document them through the supply chain. Bantam manufactures a product line of rPET flakes and pellets using ocean-bound plastic waste. Through the partnership, both companies aim to provide complete traceability of Bantam's rPET products using Oceancycle's certification of the materials. Ocean bound plastic is the term given to any plastic waste found within 50 km distance of ocean coastline. According to experts, an at-risk ocean area is any regional area which lacks waste management, suffers from overpopulation and where plastic pollution poses a serious threat to wildlife. Through the Certified Ocean Bound Plastic collaboration, Bantam aims to allow tracking the rPET materials back to at-risk areas such as SouthEast Asia, the Galapagos, the Mediterranean, and the Caribbean. Bantam uses ocean-bound plastic to produce a line of rPET products like:PelletsFlakesBalesPreformWith Certified Ocean Bound Plastic, Bantam and Oceancycle allow tracking of materials used to make these products. Tracking is allowed at all points of the supply chain, mainly:CollectionRecyclingProduction-Ready MaterialAdditionally, the collaboration allows tracking through purchasing notes, delivery notes, scale trucks, dedicated controllers.Through the system, customers, brands, and partners can trace the materials used for the rPET products back to the at-risk ocean areas from where the plastic waste was sourced. Bantam also provides auditing and quality check services of its products ensuring compliance with standards and application requirements. The company sells its products into developed economies like those in the UK, Europe, North America, and Australia. All Bantam products are in compliance with FDA, REACH and EFSA standards.

name: Barber: Beach cleaning equipment that picks up plastic waste effortlessly
remarks: H. Barber & Sons, Inc. is a family owned and operated corporation, principally located in Naugatuck, Connecticut, USA. The company is a world leader in beach cleaning equipment for more than 45 years. Barber beach cleaners easily remove unwanted seaweed, cigarettes, glass, shells, coral, stones, rocks, sticks, and man-made debris from wet and dry sand with ease.Barber  offers three models of SURF RAKE beach cleaners and two smaller sand-sifting units, the SAND MAN 850 and TT. The Barber SURF RAKEs are the highest quality, most efficient beach maintenance machinery available. Backing up this claim is the fact that Barber has sold more beach cleaners around the world than any other brand. Barber equipment is being used on six continents and in over 90 countries. The SURF RAKE's ability to clean a variety of beach conditions and its reputation of quality and dependability has earned H. Barber & Sons the distinction of being the leader in beach grooming technology and the largest manufacturer of beach cleaners in the world. Similarly, the SAND MAN line provides an excellent option to clean smaller sandy areas that may not require the SURF RAKE'S size and cleaning capacity.In addition to beach cleaners, they also manufacture stone pickers and litter collection machines. Barber stone pickers level the work area and remove rocks, sticks, stones, and other debris in one pass. A variety of models with multiple soil grooming applications, including stone removal, seed bed preparation, de-thatching, ball field cleaning, and horse arena purification are available. Barber litter collection machines are for both paved surfaces and grass areas. Truck towed and tractor towed models for all applications; such as, highway shoulder cleanup (retreads, mufflers, etc.), highway median cleaning, parking lot maintenance, sports field cleaning, and de-thatching.

name: Blue Ocean Gear: Connected, intelligent fishing gear for commercial fishing fleets
remarks: Blue Ocean Gear has developed Smart Buoy technology that allows fishermen to track and locate their fishing gear.Lost fishing gear has global economic and environmental impacts on the ocean, as well as the people and industries that rely on it. Despite fishermens best efforts, fishing gear is lost due to many uncontrollable forces including storms and strong currents. Lost gear continues fishing indiscriminately—both target species and bycatch—without being harvested. This ghost gear depletes the current biomass, reduces future harvests and fishing industry revenue.              Blue Ocean Gears Smart Buoy technology tracks fishing gear at all times, including traps and nets that are far offshore. These buoys alert fishermen of their new location when gear has moved too far, allowing for direct retrieval rather than aimless searching. A wide variety of data from the buoys can be used to help ocean businesses run more efficient and cost-effective operations, both on- and off-shore.Blue Ocean Gears Mission aligns strongly with the UN SDG 14 by addressing marine pollution and working toward sustainable fisheries. They want the ocean to be around for us to use today and far into the future. They have partnered with the Global Ghost Gear Initiative, Hardware Club, Point Blue Conservation Science, and Launch Alaska.  They are currently actively testing in three distinct markets with a steady pipeline through 2021.

name: BluePhin: Manufacturing an intelligent autonomous waste collecting robot powered by AI
remarks: FENBITS Technology Solutions private limited was formed in 2017 as an emerging start-up company offering effective, lower-cost, robust methods in the field of water pollution control, river cleaning and environmental conservation. They are innovators committed to combat water pollution, preserving natural resources, protecting biodiversity, combating climate change and raising environmental awareness.They shape, design and develop patented innovative technologies by integrating unmanned systems technology, robotics, marine construction and water treatment methods to create a dynamic solution.They have developed a waste-collecting aquadrone called BluePhin. BluePhin utilizes AI technology and can collect 770 pounds (350 kg) of trash in two hours. It is an eco friendly robot with zero carbon emissions. It has a battery capacity of 16 hours. It is equipped with a smart waste basket and an automatic lid that closes when the basket is full of trash, thus providing a secure waste collection system.

name: Bureo: Products from recycled fishing nets
remarks: Bureo was founded in 2013, based in the US and Chile, is focused on finding solutions for the growing issue of plastic pollution in our oceans and initiating social change. Bureos Net+Positiva program works together with fishermen to provide a positive solution for their end of life fishing gear, which Bureo transforms into highly recyclable and durable raw materials.Headquartered in California, Bureo is a certified B-Corporation. It is a participating company in Patagonia's Tin Shed Ventures Fund, an internal fund supporting likeminded start-up companies having a positive impact on the environment.Bureo makes items from recycled fishing nets. Their recycling program in Chile, 'Net Positiva', provides fishing net collection points to keep plastic fishing nets out of our oceans. Preventing harmful materials from entering the ocean, the programs protect wildlife and supporting local fishing communities through financial incentives.Once collected, the nets are washed and prepared for a mechanical recycling process. Within this process, they are shredded and fed through a 'pelletizer', where they are melted and cut into small recycled pellets. These pellets are then injected into steel molds to form their products. Bureo is working with industry leading companies to incorporate their materials called NetPlus into their supply chains. Collaborating with organizations that are willing to go beyond industry standards, Bureo is working closely with these partners to expand and replicate responsible material solutions. Together they can create a net positive impact on our ocean environment.Some of the products they make in collaboration with different companies are:Patagonia: using Netplus for the brim stiffeners in the hatsHumanscale: The first ergonomic task chair made with recycled fishing nets.Smart Ocean Chair: Each chair incorporates almost 2 pounds of recycled fishing net material.Costa Sunglasses: The Untangled Collection has frames constructed from 100% recycled fishing nets and are fit with mineral glass lenses.Jenga Ocean: Jenga® Ocean™ & Bureo. The first board game made from recycled fishing nets. Jenga Ocean is made from over 25 square feet of nets proudly sourced through Bureo's Net Positiva recycling program.Carver Skateboards: 'The Ahi', a performance skateboard made from recycled fishing nets. Futures Fins: The first surf fins made from recycled fishing nets, Futures' Alpha line incorporates Bureo's NetPlus recycled fishing nets with Futures' Compound 6 carbon and air infused technology.They have created a positive impact since 2013, with over 185,000 kg of materials collected to date from 26 participating communities in Chile.

name: Clear Blue Sea: Solar-powered, semi-autonomous Floating Robot For Eliminating Debris (FRED) that cleans oceans
remarks: Description: Our Concept of Operations is to implement fleets of 100s of FREDs, ranging in size from 50-100 feet, for cleanup of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, coastlines, bays, estuaries, and rivers. FREDs will operate autonomously in the ocean gyres, except when they need human intervention, at which point the Clear Blue Sea staff in our mission control center will take over FRED navigation and perform remote control of FREDs operations and routing.FREDs architecture is comprised of a simple set of subsystems:VESSEL PLATFORM SUBSYSTEM  The supporting elements of FREDs architecture are the hulls and cross beams, which support debris collection and power, and enable FRED to float in marine environments. Hulls can be made from various materials, such as commercial pontoons or fiberglass hulls, or they can be made from raw materials.	DEBRIS COLLECTION SUBSYSTEM FRED utilizes booms, belts, and bins to capture and store floating marine plastic and debris polluting the environment. The booms, which are floating arms attached to the hull frame, guide floating plastic pollution up onto the conveyor belt, and can be made of plastic, metal, or composite material. The conveyor belt, which is powered by motors receiving electricity from the Power Subsystem, is attached to the hull frame for stability. Marine debris is taken by FREDs conveyor belt to an embedded storage bin, which is sized appropriately for one mission and is able to drain water to lighten the load. POWER SUBSYSTEM FRED is designed to use sustainable energy. To capture the suns energy, FRED utilizes an array of marine-worthy solar panels forming the roof of the vessel. Solar panels can be in the form of flexible, malleable material, or rigid planes that are individually framed. Onboard batteries store electrical energy generated from the solar panels.NAVIGATION SUBSYSTEM FREDs hulls are propelled forward using electrical motors which receive electricity from the solar panel/battery assembly. Propulsion by the motors can be made autonomous or performed via remote control.SENSOR SUBSYSTEM FREDs architecture provides a platform for embedding scientific sensors and instrumentation to be used for collecting data and samples from the environment. Some sensors provide performance information, such as FREDs speed and location, and other sensors capture weather data, such as air and water temperature, wind speed, and current strength. FREDs sensors are powered by solar energy.DATA COMMUNICATIONS SUBSYSTEMWhile FRED is in marine environments, its data communications capability enables commands to be transmitted from ground control to FRED and operational data to be transmitted from FRED to ground control. This enables remote control, navigational routes, and display of FRED operational data. Our 50-foot FRED is designed to deliver the following enhanced capabilities per our system requirements baseline:•	Collect floating marine plastic and debris ranging in size from 5mm to 5 meters on a 24/7 basis•	Propel at 2 knots to prevent unannounced infringement on marine life•	Navigate autonomously based on GPS trajectory commands from mission control staff•	Navigate under remote control during unsafe conditions (storms, etc.)•	Utilize only solar power for FRED operations with stored energy available on cloudy days  •	Provide excess stored energy to governmental and commercial marine Underwater Autonomous Vehicles (UAVs) for recharging their batteries without having to return to land•	Alert marine mammals of FRED proximity using appropriate acoustic pingers recommended by marine scientists at Scripps Institute of Oceanography•	Capture environmental, oceanographic, and marine ecosystem data in real-time for transmittal to designated scientific, governmental, and commercial information systems•	Transmit sensor and instrumentation data to ground-based mission control systems for Clear Blue Sea staff to monitor, govern, and control fleets of FREDs as requiredPlastic recovery capacity: A scaled-up version of FRED (50 feet long by 30 feet wide), which will be used in Hawaii for our Phase III Pilot Program, will collect an estimated 750 cubic yards of plastic, per FRED, per year. Using the weight of a large plastic bottle, this equates to 56,250 pounds of collected plastic each year, for each FRED in the fleet.

name: Divers Clean Action: Real time maps of underwater debris
remarks: Divers Clean Action (DCA) aims to use maps created by volunteer divers to locate sunken debris as a step against marine pollution. They also seek to promote sustainable marine tourism in Indonesia's beaches, and serve as an accessible platform to find data regarding Indonesia's marine environmental issues.Founded in 2015, DCA has over 1000 volunteers to help expand their database, as well as participate in dives to locate and map marine debris in the Indonesian oceans.To help spread awareness about aquatic pollution, DCA utilises The Indonesian Youth Marine Debris Summit (IYMDS) as a fully funded program to educate Indonesian youth on marine debris, and elicit creative ideas and solutions for the issue. To combat the ever-concerning pollution of our oceans, DCA has started a number of movements. They have collaborated with KFC to start the No Straw Movement, and have started decreasing plastic straw usage all over Jakarta.They also began the Bottle2Fashion movement, a collaboration with H&M Indonesia, to covert plastics from items such as bottles to wearable fashion.

name: Ecoalf: Quality clothing created from recycled materials of the worlds' oceans
remarks: Ecoalf is a fashion company based in Madrid that creates its entire clothing line using recycled materials including plastic bottles, tyres, coffee waste and fishing nets. The company was created in 2009 with the aim of creating a sustainable model to reduce the burden on the worlds' natural resources as well as the amount of waste produced by large industries. The company has launched a range of clothing and shoes made from nylon, wool, cotton and rubber gathered debris collected from the oceans, primarily off the Spanish and/or Thailand Coast. The Ecoalf Foundation involves over 3000 fishermen in 37 ports, adding a total of 550 trawlers and collecting more than 330 tons of garbage from the ocean-beds. Various components are used in the manufacturing process, such as:Discarded Fishing nets,PET Plastic Bottles,Post-Industrial cottons and wool.Some of their shoes collection have a water repellent outerwear made from post-consumer coffee grounds. The company has an agreement with a large coffee chain in Taiwan to take their used grounds, dry them out, refine them into a powder and mix them with recycled plastic polymers to create a new fabric (and no, it does not smell like coffee).The goal of Ecoalf extends to create a recycled clothing brand with the same quality and technical advancements as non-recycled clothing brands in the market. The company is involved in the process from start to finish, be it waste collection, recycling, technologies, design or retail. Ecoalf also refrains from the use of leather in its endeavor to use only those materials which have a low environmental impact and are animal friendly. Moreover, the company refrains from the use of C6 in its water resistant clothing, relying instead on CO, meaning its products are free of PFC (Free Fluorocarbon).The Company operates three retail stores, in Madrid and Barcelona, Spain as well as Berlin, Germany and also runs an online retail store providing shipping worldwide. The organization has received the B Corporation Certificate, signifying its commitment to people and the planet.

name: Empower: Blockchain based model to pay people who collect waste plastic all over the world
remarks: Based on the idea of using technology to enable a circular economy and create a cleaner and better world, Empower was founded in January 2018. They are building a global plastic waste platform and are present in more than 20 countries throughout Europe, Africa and Asia.Empower is built on the same philosophy as the Norwegian bottle deposit system (which ensures 97% of bottles being recycled). By rewarding deposit of plastic waste, they can stop leakage of plastic into the environment, and crowdsource the collection and sorting at source of leaked waste.Their mission is that people can pick up plastic waste anywhere in the world, deliver it at a collection point and immediately receive a reward. The use of Blockchain technology ensures full transparency. They are able to track and link every deposit of plastic back to the sponsor who made it possible - thus laying the ground for real Producer Responsibility and digital Deposit Return Schemes (dDRS)Empower is also tracking the collected and registred plastic through the value chain to see where the collected plastic ends up and also making it possible for producers of recycled plastic products to show where the recycled materials is coming from while proving it is done in a responsible and socially good way. The startup is dedicated to be fully transparent in both how plastic waste collection is funded, the social and environmental impact and also where all recycled plastics are coming from and their journey from collection to new product. Empowers platform is a part of the digital infrastructure that the world needs to move from a linear to a circular economy and already in its early years we see the signs of global impact.

name: Fishy Filaments: High Quality 3D Printer Filament Made From 100% Recycled Marine Plastics
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Description: We take end-of-life nylon monofilament fishing nets direct from commercial fisheries and recycle them into raw materials for 3D printing and injection moulding. Studies are ongoing with regards to other product lines.Plastic recovery capacity: Scalable, but the standard unit will have 50 tonnes per year recycling capacity.

name: Floating Trash Barrier: Simple Collection trash system on rivers
remarks: Description: This is a passive system and does not require external energy for working. The water surface velocity does the job. It is secured on both banks or one end is anchored in water as necessary. It is deployed where the stream crosses a road or has road access. The alignment ensures that the plastics and biota lies close to one bank within reach of riverbank based gear. Boats and floating gear is not required to evacuate the collection. Floating plastics, wood, biota etc is captured by this system and mesh opening size is 10 cm x 10 cm, though it can be customized.  Where boat traffic exists the alignment can allow boat movement while  arresting trash and plastics. The alignment is different in tidal streams.  We have different models for river, stream, and smaller drains. All of them are passive systems.Plastic recovery capacity: This has recovered 22000 Tons of trash including 2200 Tons of Plastics in one year in one river. This data is as per the municipal corporation records and has been published in Media. https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/a-mountain-of-trash-fished-out-of-cooum/article26115438.ece

name: IADYS: Innovative robotic technology with Sea-neT
remarks: Description: Technical specifications: Weight: 20kgDimensions: L = 70 cm, l = 70 cm, h = 50 cmSpeed: 2 knotsEnergy: electric (3 propellers)Battery lifetime: 6 hours (2 hours recharge)Cleaning area: 1000m² / 1 knotMacro-waste collection: 80L per netOil spills collection: 30L per netOptions: autonomy, camera, waterproof smartphone, long range remote control (>1km), etc.The Jellyfishbot passively captures the waste by simply moving toward them. Also, there is no issue or risk of collecting marine life as they usually swim away from the robot. The robot can collect different type of waste thanks to its variety of nets: - Reusable micro-waste net (180/250/300 microns mesh)- Reusable milli-waste net (1mm mesh)- Reusable recycled macro-waste net (0,5 to 1cm mesh)The collected waste can be: plastic (e.g. bottles, packaging, cigarette butts), glass (e.g. floating glass bottles filled with air), metallic (e.g. cans and metal cans filled with air, organic waste (e.g. dead fish), natural debris (e.g. driftwood) and floating algae (e.g. duckweed and algae that are not filamentous or stowed at the bottom). In addition, the robot can directly collect in the net any type of floating oil. viscous type hydrocarbons (ex: oil slabs) and light type hydrocarbons (e.g. oils, gasoline, kerosene, diesel, fuel oil).With its compact size, the remote-controlled Jellyfishbot can easily access hard-to-reach and/or shallow areas where waste is usually accumulated (e.g. between boats, under the ropes, against/under docks or pontoons) in any sheltered areas such ports, marinas, lakes, ponds, etc.Plastic recovery capacity: Our nets are able to collect 80L of plastic each. After that, the user has to empty the net and reuse it to collect 80L of plastic once again. The Jellyfishbot can also clean a 1000m² surface at 1 knot speed. It is extremely easy to change the net by simply using a pole to retrieve it. There is no need to take the robot out of the water.

name: Litter Trap: Preventing plastic litter from entering seas and oceans
remarks: Description: Technical specifications:The Litter Trap is a floating device able to capture plastic litter carried by the river current or wind. CLEAR RIVERS makes the circular approach a crucial element of its strategy, therefore the Litter Traps are almost entirely made from recycled plastic retrieved from the rivers. The device is placed in the opposite direction of the water current making our product both cost-efficient and energy-autonomous. In fact, plastic debris is carried towards the opening of the Litter Trap by the current and the wind and the system does not require energy or human labour to function. Once the litter is trapped inside, it will not be able to “escape” even if the current changes direction, thanks to an innovative semi-closed- door system. Neither the instalment of the Trap nor its operation will cause any harm to the environment. In fact, CLEAR RIVERS designed openings in order to create escape routes for fish and other animals. Birds can also fly through the open part of the Trap. This is a great way to retrieve plastic litter without obstructing the pathways of aquatic organisms.After thorough analyses of the morphological and physical characteristics of rivers and canals, as well as a detailed study of wind and water currents, CLEAR RIVERS designed a modular Litter Trap (made from recycled plastic) that can be transported or shipped everywhere around the world. CLEAR RIVERS is currently developing different types of Litter Trap, where dimensions, capacity and costs change in order to be suitable for rivers and countries worldwide.Potential bottlenecks: - Risk of flooding; in rivers with an extreme fluctuation in water level, the Litter Trap needs an extra secure anchoring system.- Ship traffic; To extend the reach of the Litter Traps we attach floating booms to it to guide the floating debris into the Litter Trap. Intense ship traffic will give limitations to the placement of the booms. A way to overcome this is to have a (small) repetition of Litter Traps, to still retrieve the litter in the second Litter Trap that passed by the first instalment. Measures to avoid collection of biological components:Biological elements can enter the Litter Traps, but can easily be removed on site. The Litter Trap is accessible for emptying and the removal of any obstacles. Plastic recovery capacity: 5m3 per emptying depending on the preferred system (CLEAR RIVERS offers different dimensions for the system; scalable approach). The frequency of emptying depends on the local situation: how fast the Litter Trap fills up, due to weather conditions, pollution quantity, possibilities of local partners to empty, etc.

name: Ministry of Waste: Building large scale waste management infrastructure in developing countries.
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Description: We have created relationships with numerous local government officials and leaders in order to execute this Public-Private Partnership in a fully integrated waste management system. Our operational focus is on mid to small size/and mostly rural areas of Indonesia with a tonnage of 30t per day of mixed waste delivered to our facilities. We accept all mixed domestic waste as well as envision to help the local communities with the local industrial waste. Our technology is designed, manufactured and maintained by a fully Indonesian based team. We enable local entrepreneurs and business owners to use our sorted material in their production for a locally based economy to thrive. We plan to run regular local circular economy and design workshops to enable local capacity building.We have strong long term business partners to bring deposit return schemes and other solutions to Indonesia as well.Large investment for infrastructure is the only bottleneck for us.Plastic recovery capacity: Ministry of Waste solution has the highest plastic recovery rate possible as separating plastic out of domestic waste enables us to capture as much plastic as is collected from households, currently estimated at 40-55% of all mixed domestic waste. The total tonnage per facility depends on the input tonnage from the location. If we take minimum 30t/day input at 40% plastic, it would equal 4380t/year from the smallest unit. Some of our locations would have a tonnage input of 200t a day which would equal 14,600t/year of plastic recovered.

name: My Little Plastic Footprint: Building large scale waste management infrastructure in developing countries.
remarks: Description: The improved My Little Plastic Footprint app helps you reduce the amount of plastic in your everyday life. It gives you ideas and challenges you. You can work out the real-life challenges of avoiding plastic with the help of tips and questions that the app provides and, before you know it, you are making a difference. So, do something good for yourself and for the world – go on a plastic diet.The diet revolves around tackling the concerns about plastic affecting human health, avoiding leakage of plastic into the environment and aiming for an absolute reduction of plastic production. We provide you with more than 100 tips to reduce your plastic consumption or to replace a plastic item with a sustainable alternative.To calculate your plastic footprint, we have created the Plastic Mass Index (PMI). The PMI is a measure to calculate your contribution to plastic pollution. The closer your PMI is to zero, the less you contribute; the closer your PMI gets to 100, the more you contribute. By going on a plastic diet, you will reduce your PMI.Plastic recovery capacity: It is about reduce and refuse single-used-plastics in your personal live.

name: Net Your Problem: Coordinating the collection of old fishing nets & gears from fishermen to give them a second life
remarks: Description: We work in coastal communities to design and implement end of life fishing gear collection programs for recycling.  We create a responsible and accessible disposal option for this gear to prevent its entry into the marine environment.  This reduces the amount of biological fouling (as is commonly observed in gear recovered from the water or beach) and ensures a high quality feedstock. Gear is generally collected at fishing ports. Currently the gear that we are able to accept and send for recycling is made up of Nylon 6 (PA 6), Polypropylene (PP), and Polyethylene (PE). We are open to developing relationships with any recyclers worldwide who have this capability to reduce transportation costs and support our diverse project locations. +[@[Review the description of your solution on Ubuntoo. Please provide any additional information regarding: technical specifications, potential bottlenecks, measures (if any) to avoid collection of b...]]We would like to develop relationships with recyclers who are able to take “mixed plastics” and could accommodate gear made with Nylon 6.6 (PA 6.6) components as well as facilities with the technology to recycle lines that made of a mix of Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) and PE as well as lines that are infused with lead.Plastic recovery capacity: With the right funding mechanism for programs, there is no limit to the amount of gear that can be collected and shipped to recycling centers. End of life fishing gear is a high volume, concentrated waste stream that can be collected in large quantities in a short time period.  We have been in operation for 3 years (as of May 2020) and have collected between 109-161 mt per year from only four locations in Alaska.

name: Net-Works: Collecting discarded fishing nets from coastal communities and recycling them into carpet tiles
remarks: Net-WorksTM redesigns global supply chains to create sustainable and scalable solutions that reduce marine plastic, increase fish stocks and improve the lives of marginalized coastal communities living in biodiversity hotspots of developing countries.On the current trajectory of plastic pollution and over fishing there will be one tonne of plastic for every three tonnes of fish in the ocean by 2025. The people most affected are those in marginalized rural communities within biodiversity hotspots of the developing world, especially in Southeast Asia which contributes for over 60% of the worlds marine debris, is the center of marine biodiversity, contains 55% of the global population of artisanal reef fishers and suffers the highest level of fishing pressure.Net-Works provides a simple, scalable and holistic model to deliver less plastic, more fish and improve the lives of marginalized coastal communities across Southeast Asia by applying the principles of fair trade and inclusive business. They created efficient community-based supply chains for raw materials (plastics and seaweed carrageenan) that are available in abundance. They link these raw materials to conservation actions that reduce plastic pollution and restore coastal ecosystems. Increasing incomes from seaweed reduces dependence on fishing & enables communities to set aside larger No-Take zones (NTZs). They sell these raw materials into global supply chains, giving international brands opportunities to source premium products with positive social and environmental stories, giving fishing communities a more transparent and dependable price, and providing sustainable funding sources for local conservation and development actions. To manage local supply chains, they set up community banks, bringing communities together in informal cooperatives and providing much-needed access to financial services, using the globally recognized and proven Village Savings and Loan Association (VSLA) model. These community banks are the social glue at the heart of Net-Works, enabling members to invest in their sustainable livelihoods, building a Net-Works conservation constituency. So far they have:Collected >195 metric tonnes of nets (increasing daily) which have been recycled into high quality nylon yarn and sold to Interface, Inc. to make high design carpet tiles.Conducted successful scientific trials of ecological seaweed farming in the Philippines. They have prototyped the first bigger community-based MPA needed to replenish fish stocks, covering 627ha, with 202ha in a NTZ (up from the average12ha) in the Philippines. They are currently finalizing ordinances for a further three communities with NTZs over 200ha in size.Built the best-practice standards and toolsImproved the marine environment for 64,000 people.Received awards and recognition in the media, including the US Secretary of States Award for Corporate Excellence, MRW National Recycling Awards Business Partnership of the year (2017), Guardian Sustainable Business award for collaboration (2015) among others.

name: Ocean Bound Plastic Certifications: Certification for collecting and recycling ocean-bound plastic
remarks: Description: We developed public standards for certification bodies to audit and certify company doing collection and recycling of Ocean Bound Plastic (OBP). The Standards focus on:For the Collection Side-Where is the abandoned plastic waste collected (proof of Ocean Bound origin as per standard's definitions)-Conditions of collection (no child labor, fair working conditions)-How the plastic is then managed (recycled, valorized, landfilled,...)For the Recycling Side:-Traceability of the OBP material in the recycling value chain until the final product-Conditions of processing (no child labor, fair working conditions)-Waste management practices of facilities (to ensure especially no OBP is generated)Overall, the chain of custody verification that the Standards provide allow end users to be sure that the product they buy contains the claimed content of recycled OBP and that this OBP can be traced to its collection location.Plastic recovery capacity: OBP Certifications create incentives for collectors and recyclers to focus on Ocean Bound Plastic material having  increasing the volumes of OBP collected.

name: Ocean Sole: Social enterprise that recycles flip-flops into art
remarks: Ocean Sole is a flip-flop recycling social and environmental enterprise based in Kenya. It was inspired by the toys children made from flip-flops waste material.They collect waste from Nairobi as it has many rivers that empty into the oceans, and the company is trying to reduce marine pollution. With the recycled material they make art and functional products. In 2005 the company was formed as a means to tackle poverty and marine pollution.  Today, Ocean Sole recycles about 1000 kg of flip-flops a week and currently employs 50+ people. Besides providing jobs they also have become a center where people can bring flip-flop wastes. Their artwork includes Bahari, wall art, safari, world, and beaded bracelets. Their art has received international attention and is displayed and sold in Rome, London, New York, Paris, Amsterdam, Singapore and Australia. They have partnered with UNEP UNESCO, UNDP and UNICP as a conservation entrepreneurship. They have also raised awareness, attended conservation conferences and have hosted the biggest International Coast Clean-up (ICC) ever in Kenya.

name: OceanBound Plastics: Converting ocean-bound plastic waste into a recyclable plastic resin
remarks: Description: TDS available.Plastic recovery capacity: 140MM lbs./year

name: Oceanworks: Shore to Store collection and processing of plastic waste, using the OceansMade™ mark to showcase product authenticity
remarks: Ocean plastic is an abundant “stranded resource” that can replace the use of virgin materials and then be recycled and reused endlessly, reversing the tide of plastics filling our oceans. They are continuously adding collection sites and types of materials offered to brands in product development. 8 million metric tons of plastic enter the oceans annually. 80% of that comes from land based sources. Oceanworks, together with partners around the globe, is sustainably and ethically harvesting plastic from coastal areas where waste is mismanaged. The plastic they utilize is 100% recycled from this coastal harvest, thereby taking it out of its inevitable flow to the ocean. They collect plastic in many locations where there are no substantial financial opportunities available for people. Their mission is to create meaningful employment and positive local impact in these communities. Community sources - Global Impact They work with local collection partners around the world, creating meaningful employment and cleaner waterways. The Oceanworks team is a seasoned group of design and engineering professionals. They have deep manufacturing partnerships in Asia and have been at the forefront of sustainable design efforts before it was cool. They optimize design and manufacturing for efficiency and quality so that ocean plastic will be used most effectively. They can also help to source and manage suppliers. Oceanworks sourced plastic is documented from collection source to retail shelf. They follow the material and its collection source and then monitor the chain of custody all the way through to the final product. This gives brands and factories assurances that the ocean plastic was ethically collected for a living wage. They are working with leading experts in ocean debris, technical expertise on polymers, and waste management. Oceanworks was born out of Norton Point, an eyewear company that launched a line of ocean plastic sunglasses in 2016. Funded on Kickstarter in just 6 days, the project raised awareness of ocean plastic worldwide and opened our eyes to the many disparate elements that need to be woven together to develop a product that truly makes a difference. Ultimately, this realization led us to found Oceanworks.

name: One Earth - One Ocean: Marine vessels to collect, sort and process plastic waste from the oceans
remarks: Germany-based One Earth-One Ocean is a nonprofit organization working towards cleaning up oceans globally to free them from marine litter and oil and chemical pollution.One Earth-One Ocean (OEOO) aims to reduce the extent of ocean pollution through the concept and technology of the 'Marine Litter Cleanup'.The Marine Litter Cleanup project comprises of two collection vessels which can be used in inland waters or oceans to collect plastic waste from rivers. The project aims to collect, sort and process the waste to create recycled plastic bales along with recovering fuel and energy. So far, the project has been deployed in two stages:SeeHamster: the first generation collectors launched in 2012 have been updated to the 5th generation in 2019. These are small catamarans about four metres long and two metres wide and a fold-down net or fishing gear with which plastic garbage from inland waters is collected. The SeeHamsters are in use in Cambodia, Germany and Asia. SeeKuh: launched in Lubek in 2016, the collector can gather the waste from a depth of 4 metres. The ship, also based on the catamaran shape, has a size of 12 x 10 meters and will clean bays, estuaries and coastal sections. It is also equipped with a water analyzer which can test water samples to identify the type of waste or other sources of pollution. The SeeKuh vessels are the first to be licensed by DNV/GL worldwide. OEOO aims to make the SeeKuh vessels completely reliant on renewable energy sources like solar or wind in the future. Additionally, OEOO has launched the SeeElefant, which treats, sorts and processes the waste collected by the vessels using a plant technology that has been integrated into the ship. The SeeElefant can produce plastic bales as well as recover energy and fuel from the waste. The plastic waste is crushed and cleaned and plastics like PVC and PET are sorted out. The remaining mixture is melted and evaporated to separate chlorine and sulfur. The remaining gas is then condensed to obtain fuel. Around 30% of the fuel is consumed by the vessels and the rest can be sold to other ships and vessels. Waste processing is done in partnership with BIOFABRIK, using their WASTX Plastic technology. OEOO has also built the International Marine Litter Database, an extensive database comprising of scientific studies and findings on marine litter from around the world. One Earth-One Ocean has received a number of awards for their work, including 2017 European Inventor Award and the Federal Award for Ecodesign in 2019. The organization is supported by brands like Bruckner Group, Novus, Greenland Seafood and Denner among others.

name: Operation Clean Sweep: A stewardship program aimed at eliminating pellet loss from the plastics industry
remarks: The American Chemistry Council (ACC) and Plastics Industry Association (PLASTICS) teamed up to create the Operation Clean Sweep (OCS) stewardship program. The program focuses on helping the plastics industry reduce the accidental loss of pellets, flakes, and powder from processing facilities into the environment.The OCS program provides partner companies with a manual of procedures to help ensure minimal accidental loss to the environment during plant operations. The manual provides solutions to contain, reclaim, and dispose of resin pellets properly. ACC and PLASTICS encourage participating companies to sign onto the Declaration for Solutions to Marine litter, of which the OCS program is a key element.The OCS implementation program involves signing the pledge, assessing your company's situation and needs, making necessary upgrades to facilities and equipment, raising employee awareness, creating accountability, and following up, and enforcing procedures.

name: Parley: Creaters, Thinkers and Leaders collaborate to end ocean pollution
remarks: Parley is the space where creators, thinkers, and leaders come together to raise awareness for the beauty and fragility of our oceans and collaborate on projects that can end their destruction. Parley AIR is the strategy to end marine plastic pollution. Everyone has a role to play. Start by taking the Parley AIR pledge, then put words into action with their summer challenge to ban one plastic item from your life, post your pledge on social with #ParleyAIR, Tag others to challenge them. Parley AIR can solve the fast-growing threat of plastic pollution. They believe plastic is a design failure, which can only be solved by reinventing the material itself. We can stop producing more plastic right away and use up-cycled marine plastic waste instead. Let's invent our way out of this mess. Together. Hence,: Avoid plastic whenever possible, Intercept Plastic Waste, Redesign the material itself

name: PingMe: Helping fishermen locate lost gear and keeping ocean clean
remarks: OSAC's PingMe helps fishermen locate and identify lost gear in the ocean. PingMe is a smart and modern tool for tagging gear and objects under water. With new transponder technology, either integrated with the boat's sonar or as a stand-alone system, PingMe makes it easy to find and identify lost gear underwater.Ghost fishing and lost gear (mostly gill-nets) from the fisheries represent a major environmental problem. For the fisheries, this is also linked to reputation. Lost gear means financial loss and reduced efficiency for the fisherman. Lost gear is also a danger to those traveling by sea. Tagging gear for easier detection is likely to be regulated in the future.PingMe is patented and consists of three units:PingMe transponder: A smart, small device attached to gear/objects you want identified and located underwaterPingMe software: A software module integrated in the boat's existing sonar system or as a stand-alone system.  The software allows communication with the transponder to determine location and ID.PingMe Service in the cloud: A management tool for the authorities. Information of lost, detected and retrieved gear is reported to the cloud, some of it automatically. This enables the authorities to keep better control of litter in the ocean, which might come in conflict with other boats or fisheries.Ocean Space Acoustics (OSAC) is an innovative company that contributes to a sustainable fishery and a cleaner ocean through its solutions. Basic technology is being developed in collaboration with SINTEF, Norway's largest research institute.

name: Pinovo: Patented technology for dust-free vacuum blasting of industrial surfaces
remarks: Pinovo offers an innovative vacuum blasting technology to reduce the amount of microplastics that end up in Norwegian oceans when old paint is removed from industrial surfaces. Pinovos technology and surface maintenance tools drastically reduce waste and emissions and protect the marine ecosystem and human food chain.   While paints are essential for protecting offshore steel structures from corrosion, due to the salt content in oceans, the removal of old paint from the steel surfaces leads to ocean pollution. Currently, the 12-billion-dollar sandblasting industry produces heavy metals, toxic dust, and microplastics too.Pinovo has developed an ATEX-certified closed loop grip basting technology, which is also known as vacuum blasting or dust-free blasting. This technology helps customers save money, improve HSE, and also protect the environment without any compromise being made on the quality of the work. Some of its products are:PiBlast: An automated, fully pneumatic, closed-loop vacuum blasting tool intended for dust-free abrasive blasting of straight pipes.PiCo Pipe: A hand-held closed-loop vacuum blasting tool intended for dust-free abrasive blasting of pipes.PiHab: A flexible, transparent, abrasive blasting enclosure to be used with the Pinovo vacuum blasting units PiSys.PiWalk: A walk-behind tool primarily intended for dust-free vacuum blasting of medium-sized flat or walkable inclined surfaces.PiConnect: A versatile, hand-held closed-loop vacuum blasting tool primarily intended for spot and sweep blasting. Due to the click-on adapter technology, a variety of surface geometries can be blast cleaned easily.PiPoint: A hand-held closed-loop vacuum blasting tool primarily intended for small spots with difficult access.PiSys: A fully pneumatic ATEX certified closed-loop vacuum blasting and recycling unit, designed for dust-free abrasive blastingAll Pinovo products are safe to use, and make activities like blasting, sheeting, cleaning, and painting efficient. Other work disciplines or surrounding equipment are not affected by them. Some other advantages are their low noise emissions, less dust and grit production, low vibration, ergonomic design, light weight, and a robust waste management system.    Pinovo supports the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, to prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution by 2025, and achieve the environmentally sound management of chemicals and all wastes by 2020.Some companies that Pinovo works with are Shell, Equinor, EDF, AkerBP, Chevron, Repsol Sinopec, and the Norwegian Armed Forces.Their technology is an ideal solution for companies looking for offshore industrial painting and cleaning services. Pinovos distributors are located in France, Benelux, USA, Canada, and Trinidad.

name: Plastic Bank: Stopping ocean plastic while improving the lives of collector communities
remarks: Description: How it WorksIn Plastic Bank recycling ecosystems, collectors collect ocean-bound plastic (plastic collected within 30 miles of the ocean or waterway leading to an ocean) and deposit their recyclables at a local Plastic Bank branch or certified partner location. The plastic is sorted by type and colour, then weighed. The corresponding value is deposited into their digital account. Plastic Bank members receive a bonus in addition to the market value for their plastic. This ensures Plastic Bank members receive a stable and fair earned income. They can store and redeem the value at any time at a Plastic Bank branch or certified partner location.When a collector registers with Plastic Bank they receive a blockchain-secured digital wallet, virtual identity information, trust score and credit score. Through the digital platform, collectors and their families can become eligible for health insurance and school tuition. Our co-op community model empowers co-op members to gain co-op voting rights, equal profit sharing and shared ownership of their local programs.A branchs ongoing participation with Plastic Bank requires that they comply with Plastic Banks code of conduct for transparent ethical sourcing and maintain the required trust scores and standing.Types of Plastic Collected- Mixed Plastic- HDPE- PET- PP- PS- LDPE- PVC- ABS- Caps- Custom PlasticsBuilt for TrustPlastic Banks platform is designed for unlimited scale while maintaining speed, transparency and security through the use of IBMs enterprise-level technology stack. The technology stack utilizes blockchain and HyperLedger Fabric on private LinuxOne servers and the IBM Cloud.Utilizing the power of blockchain, Plastic Bank has created a tokenized reward system. Plastic Bank digital tokens act as loyalty points or credits, earned by recycling, with a guaranteed liquidation value of 0.01 USD per token. This system securely provides savings, cashless spending, and instant value distribution, with guaranteed delivery of the value promised to the members.Plastic Bank digital rewards can only be created by Plastic Bank. Digital rewards are not available through a public exchange. The creation of a token is matched with funds in a bank account controlled by Plastic Bank. Bonus rewards are instantly unlocked to eligible members at the time of exchange per kilogram of eligible material. In most programs, branches receive a distribution/reporting bonus upon verified re-sale of the equivalent amount of materials they rewarded to their collectors. Creating end-to-end trust and audibility.Impact MetricsSince the starting operations in Haiti in 2016, Plastic Bank has achieved the following impact:- 13,396,103 kg of plastic prevented from entering the ocean - thats the equivalent of 669,805,150 plastic bottles- 20,692 total collectors engaged- 9374 women collectors- 320 collection branches - Over 100,000 transactions- Equivalent of over $600,000 in bonus rewards distributed- Recognized for achieving 14 of 17 United Nations Sustainable Development Goals- Over 75 corporate partners - 10 of which have incorporated Social Plastic® into their products and packagingPlastic recovery capacity: Plastic Bank is increasing momentum and is now collecting approximately 1 million kilograms of plastic per month across our global operations. 1041483 kg collected in June 2020, and 1,200,202 kg collected in July 2020. Collection numbers are verified using our proprietary blockchain platform.

name: Plastic Soup Surfer: Awareness campaigns to end plastic marine waste
remarks: Description: Organising impact by lobbying on European level and in the meanwhile focussing and giving the community of plastic activists the tools and inspirationPlastic recovery capacity: This would reduce litter by plastic bottles by roughly 1 bilion pieces a year in Europe

name: Plastic Vortex: floating device that captures floating waste from rivers
remarks: Based in Toulouse, France; Plastic Vortex is a system that captures floating plastic waste from rivers using a device that does not use any electrical or fuel power.Nearly 80% of the waste pollution in the oceans comes from urban pollution through rivers. Plastic Vortex aims to reduce such upstream pollution using a simple system that captures the waste floating down rivers.The Plastic Vortex system consists of a floating platform connected with floating arms that make a V-shape. The system faces the downstream flow of a river. All floating waste is captured by the arms and directed towards the platform at the centre.The waste is transferred to a tub by a conveyor belt, which is rotated by turbines that run on the river currents and not on electricity or fuel. The tub is carried to the shore using a hand-operated pulley.The floating devices and arms are made of waste materials like plastic bottles.The Plastic Vortex team visits the system, which is installed on the Garrone river, several times during the week depending on the weather conditions. They recover an average of thirty plastic bottles at each visit. The system which has so far collected 112 kilograms of floating waste including 1,083 plastic bottles. The inventor is seeking €35,000 through a crowdfunding campaign to produce and deploy its second system in 2020. It is doing research to make the system more reliable and aims to deploy it on other rivers in the Occitanie region and eventually in all of France.Its partners include Orange Foundation, Dassault Systems, FAB14+, and Artilect.

name: Plasticoin: Virtual currency in exchange for plastic waste
remarks: Plasticoin is a project in Uruguay that uses virtual currency to incentivize consumers to recycle plastic waste. The currency can be used at restaurants and stores.Nearly 13 million tonnes of plastic waste is not recycled and ends up in the worlds oceans, according to the United Nations. In Uruguay, a country of 3.4 million people, only 35% of plastic waste is collected for recycling.Plasticoin aims to incentivize consumers to deposit their plastic waste in return for virtual currency. The project is undergoing pilot tests at a seaside resort in Piriapolis city on the countrys Atlantic Ocean coast:Consumers can register online and deposit plastic waste from their household or collected from the beach at one of the three designated collection centers. They receive Plasticoin currency on their phone based on the weight and type of waste discarded. The minimum waste is one kg, for which they receive Plasticoins. To promote clean coastal zones, plastic waste and microplastic removed from beaches and oceans results in a higher Plasticoin payment.The customers can use the currency to get discounts at partnered shops and restaurants. These include yoga centers, surfboard shops, and shops selling bags, toothbrushes, pizza, haircuts, and coffee, among other products.Plasticoins launched in January 2020 with a grant of $5000 from the Uruguan governments National Development Agency. The project received more than a thousand users within three weeks, against a target of 100 users in a month.The project is looking for companies that can provide discounts on their products to Plasticoin users. It is also looking for companies to advertise on the Plasticoin platform. Based on the number of Plasticoins received by the company, it can claim tax benefits under a 2019 law passed in the country.

name: Plastix: Transforming waste fishing nets and trawls into plastic raw materials
remarks: Plastix is a leading Danish clean tech company which transforms waste fishing nets and waste rigid plastics into high quality plastic raw materials. Plastix has developed a proprietary technology and process system to handle very tough waste fractions such as trawls and nets. The fishing waste they collect provides raw material for producing secondary plastic material that they sell.The high quality plastic collected and recycled from oceans is called OceanIX and the one recycled from land waste is called NordIX. Both these plastics can be used by themselves or in a blend for producing new items. Regular users of their material can get a certificate as “Certified Recyclates User of Discarded Fishing Net and Trawl” to show as CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility) achievements. They remind their clients that using their green material saves precious fossil fuels, reduces plastic pollution on land and oceans, and reduces CO2 emissions.Plastix has been co-funded by the European Union within the CIP Eco-Innovation initiative of the Competitiveness and Innovation Framework Programme (CIP) through the Retrawl project. Plastix is located in Lemvig, Denmark and operates in Scandinavia, the Baltic Region, most of Europe and South Africa.Their technology transforms an extensive disposal/deposit problem – discarded fishing nets and other post-use plastic waste fractions –  into valuable recycled HDPE and PP plastics raw materials.Awareness of environmental impacts, geopolitics and a focus on increasing efficiency in the collecting of waste streams has created incentives for the fishing industry to stop dumping used fishing gear into the ocean, thus moving the issue to on-shore handling of nets and other types of gear.Their creativity for solutions derives from the imagination, designs, innovations, strategies and collective implementation methodologies that meet the diverse needs of their clients and partners. Through the use of technology, they provide treatment methods that have shown the ability to effectively recycle plastics and metals from net and trawl without downgrading the quality and thereby losing valuable resources. With their recycling technology the used maritime materials can be recycled 100% in a closed loop.

name: Plymouth Marine Laboratory: Technique tracking plastic debris in the ocean from space
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Plymouth Marine Laboratory (PML) is a charity that aims to develop and apply innovative marine science to ensure a sustainable future for the ocean. Working in association with national and international partners, they have conducted research and implemented solutions.Among their research is a project that utilizes satellites to detect ocean plastics. The Sentinel-2 satellites will allow PML scientists to assess oceanic changes and assist in managing impacts in human-affected inland water and marine environments. Using satellite imagery, patches of floating plastics can be detected and mapped. This technology is 86% accurate at distinguishing plastics from naturally occurring floating materials.The research team continues to improve their methods to increase accuracy in large river systems and turbid coastal waters. The results of their research can help inform the development of improved international agreements to effectively combat the marine plastics problem.PML was the first organization to identify that microplastics are damaging to zooplankton and was instrumental in the scientific reasoning behind the UK legislation that banned microplastic beads. PML continues its outreach activities globally to increase public awareness of the global plastic issue and to urge policymakers and manufacturers to act.

name: Project STOP: Creating a comprehensive waste management system to stop ocean plastics leakage
remarks: Description: The world is struggling to answer the question: How do we stop ocean plastic leakage permanently, and do so as quickly and efficiently as possible? Permanent reduction results from solving the complex root causes behind mismanaged waste, deeply tied to the interwoven economic, regulatory, technical, social and behavioural norms of a region. Solutions need to be found that are culturally appropriate, inclusive, economically sustainable, technically rigorous, and built on a foundation of transparent, reliable governance, all of which takes time to develop. Yet, we are in a plastic crisis and need to move and scale quickly without neglecting the fundamental building blocks required for systemic change.  To do this, first, we must focus our time and resources where it matters most - on the locations with the highest pollution levels coupled with strong government and local commitment. We then need to unearth local collective wisdom and leadership, to quickly get to what will work and co-develop a plan forward that everyone can stand behind to develop economically sustainable, circular, zero leakage waste systems. We also need to ensure sufficient revenue is available to cover the costs of each waste system, especially in Indonesia where waste funding is generally insufficient.Project STOP partners with cities and local government to build resilient and economically sustainable waste systems that eliminate leakage of plastics into the environment and ocean.  Nearly 80% of plastic waste in aquatic ecosystems comes from land sources. About 50% of this comes from emerging countries like Indonesia, China, Philippines, Vietnam and Thailand. Project STOP aims to assist countries like Indonesia who have pledged to reduce the country ocean levels by 70% by 2025. This is to be done by helping establish an effective waste management system in the country.  Launched in 2017, Project STOP is an initiative co-founded by Borealis and SYSTEMIQ that designs, implements, and scales circular economy solutions to prevent plastic pollution in Southeast Asia. Project STOP supports cities with experienced waste management, plastic recycling, organic waste management, community engagement, behavior change and program governance experts.
