The team works in a simple system: •	Scoping: Assessing cities for ocean pollution and government involvement. •	Preparation & Design: Stakeholder agreements to build an effective waste management system. •	Implementation: Equip the community to operate the waste management system economically. •	Scale Up: Expanding to new regions to establish change.  Working with companies, local governments and community groups, Project STOP also aims o create new jobs in waste management and reduce the harmful impact of mismanaged waste on public health, tourism and fisheries. Project STOPs long-term ambition is to establish new solutions and models that can be rapidly scaled-up across the whole plastics chain, from the uses of plastic to waste collection and recycling, in areas where there is need to improve the management of plastic waste. Project STOP currently works in the coastal cities of  Muncar (Population: 130,000 inhabitants) in East Java, Lekok and Ngulign in Pasuruan (Population: 130,000 inhabitants) in East Java, and Jembrana (Population: 160,000 inhabitants) in northwest Bali.  Along with co-founders SYSTEMIQ and Borealis, Project Stops strategic partners include the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Nova Chemicals, Nestlé, Alliance to End Plastic Waste and Borouge.Plastic recovery capacity: We collect all the plastic waste generated. We sort it and based on our capture rate (40-70% - depending on facility) and our available markets we sell the plastic to aggregators. In Indonesia, a city of 100k people produce annually ~1,500 tons of plastics. Our aim is to achieve >90% collection coverage within 2 years.

name: ReCleanSea: Industrial solutions for ocean plastics collection & recycling
remarks: ReCleanSea is a non-profit organisation that is developing a unique system designed to clean up, on an industrial level, large polluted regions where floating plastic trash has accumulated with currents, winds or waves in rivers, estuaries or coastal areas. Leveraging 15+ years of experience collecting trash and heavy oil at sea and in freshwaters with small to mid-size collectors, they are building a massive apparatus. They leverage their founders 20-year experience in designing, building and operating industrial systems to tow extra-wide underwater imaging tools, as well as oil and plastic trash collectors, like the 150 small ones that the French Navy uses to protect the French coasts from oil spills.The trash collectors can be anchored in rivers or estuaries, or towed by one or two fishing or work boats in any area, after a simple half-day training session. As such, they can benefit any local community all over the world.Their proof of concept consists in building an extra-wide collector, to be towed by an existing ship, itself modified to accommodate an onboard plastic treatment unit for sorting the trash and possibly testing some recycling features. Their XXL collector is scalable, thanks to parts that are 100 m wide each, which allows it to reach 500 m in width and 700 m in length.Towed by the ship in various sea conditions during their test campaign, the extra-wide collector will sweep a large area polluted with ocean plastics. Plastic debris will accumulate in the filtering net at the tip of the collector, which is pulled back to the ship when full. Once onboard, the filtering net will be emptied onto the ship, and the plastic will be sorted and processed for recycling, while the filtering net will return to sea for another sweep.The collectors have never caught any fish in 15 years of operation. When they are towed, its at the very slow speed of 2 knots, which gives fish plenty of time to feel the draft and move away, especially as the immersed skirts of the collector are not deep. When the collectors are anchored in a river, they also let any marine life escape the current towards the filtering net.Founding partners have contributed to a starting budget to promote the project and look for investors. They are in talks with different public and private entities, internationally, to wrap their budget.They estimate the cost of the extra-wide collector alone at €800K. Adding the cost of research and studies, of modifying the ship to accommodate a treatment unit and of course the cost of the test campaign at sea, they have budgeted €5M for the proof of concept.As for any trash collection and recycling process, they believe in a combination of two main factors to make this a sustainable business model:There is a specific market for recycled ocean plastic as a raw material, with higher value than land plastic.Considering the actual cost of plastic pollution, loss of revenues from fisheries and tourism, and serious damages to the environment, they believe that ocean plastic recovery, even subsidised, is a matter of survival for natural ecosystems and mankind.They aim to build the collector in 2019 and have the test campaign at sea in 2019-2020.They are looking for partners and investors to support the first series of tests of the proof of concept and to support the association. They can be reached at  +33 7 61 09 23 51 or via email at contact@ReCleanSea.org

name: Renew Oceans: A solution to reduce ocean plastic pollution at the source
remarks: Renew Oceans is a non-profit organization working to reduce ocean plastic pollution where it begins—in populous, river-adjacent communities in the developing world. Their vision is to create highly scalable, circular economies for plastics in river communities which are known to be the biggest contributors of ocean plastic pollution—starting with the Ganges basin. The Renew Oceans strategy leverages science, technology, and human capital to achieve their ambitious goals. Their inaugural project, Renew Ganga, is the centerpiece of their efforts to divert ocean-bound plastics in India, empowering local women and others in Varanasi to help protect rivers and oceans from plastic pollution.Renew Oceans aims to solve the problem of plastic pollution by using an integrated approach toward collection planning, conversion technology, and community engagement.Renew Oceans is focused on the collection of both hard and soft plastics through both river- and land-based methods, leveraging innovative technologies including ReFences and Reverse Vending Machines (RVMs). They have implemented conversion of traditionally low value film and flexible plastics via RenewOne into renewable fuel to address the lack of end markets for soft plastics. Lastly, their community engagement campaigns foster changes in longstanding habits and perceptions. Renew Oceans works with students and community leaders, and their empowerment of and financial incentives for women waste pickers, builds momentum and drives adoption of new behaviors.Renew Oceans' initiatives are sponsored by the Alliance to End Plastic Waste with support from Happy Family Organics. In their first year, over 100,000 pounds of waste was diverted from the Assi River tributary, and more than 1,000 community members were engaged. In 2020, they aim to double that, diverting over 200,000 pounds of waste and engaging 10,000 members of the community in their work.Governments, NGOs, waste collection & disposal companies, and bioenergy companies are potential clients.

name: Seabin Smart Tech including Pollution Index: Autonomous floating waste collection device for harbors, coastlines and waterways
remarks: Description: Seabin focus on Clean Up and Prevention For Clean Up:Seabin smart tech is used as an “active water based” capturing technology. The Seabin unit is installed in a strategic upstream location where marine litter converges naturally. Generally Ports, Marinas and City foreshores are the main installation points. Each unit filters 600,000 litres of water per day for micro plastics, oil, surface pollutants and general plastics including plastic fibers. Currently the global average capture is 3.9Kgs per day or 1.4 tons of marine litter per year. The cost to filter 600,000 litres of water is AUD$3.31 per day. The units are also solar compatible.The next Seabin 6.0 is currently in production and will be incorporating under water sensors to monitor electrical conductivity, dissolvable oxygen and water temp as baseline data. The sensor technology is also designed as an appendage to be swapped out for other more relevant sensors to that region. Seabin are now offering services for citys and governments which not only include the daily empties and quarterly maintenance, but also the weekly data sets for the Pollution Index® For Prevention:Seabin Foundation use education and community initiatives combined with the Pollution Index® data monitoring program.The Pollution Index® (PI) program is operational in 19 countries with a network of 71 volunteers uploading data sets weekly of what the Seabin smart tech is capturing.Currently a Pollution Index® data app is being developed and will be operational by December 2020.Plastic recovery capacity: Daily: 3.9 kgs per unitPer Year – 1.4 tons per unit Global fleet is 860 units- daily capture is 3.6 tons per day and 500 million litres of water filtered per day Each unit has the capacity to catch:90,000 plastic bags / year35,700 coffee cups / year16,500 plastic water bottle s/ year166,500 plastic utensils

name: SEAQUAL: Polyester fabric from ocean waste
remarks: Seaqual is a different kind of filament which is made by recycling the plastic collected at the bottom of the sea. Working together with fishermen in the collection of all sorts of plastic polluting the bottom of our oceans, Seaqual then transform PET into high quality yarn that goes straight into fabrics and clothing. Dealing with the inconsistency of the debris removed by the fishermen that results from exposure to sun, salt and water, required many months of investment in R&D. They are now able to create a 100% recycled polyester filament of the highest quality.Collecting debris directly from the sea, not the beaches or the coast make this project absolutely unique in its proposal. For collecting the plastic waste, more than 400 boats and 1500 Fishermen from the Spanish Mediterranean coast are involved in the project. Garbage caught in the fishermens nets is collected every day and taken to different ports. The waste is collected weekly, they are classified and categorized so that each material (aluminum, glass, pet plastic,) goes to its unique recycling chain. The PET Plastic is accumulated for conversion into flakes and later into polymer. The polymer can be used to make fabrics and then garments and thus completing the cycle.

name: StormX Netting Trash Trap: Collection nets for stormwater runoff
remarks: Description: The Bandalong Litter Traps and StormX Netting Trash Traps are passive capturing systems that require no energy other than the natural current or flow.  The Bandalong is used in creeks, rivers, canals, or channel waterways to capture floating litter and debris and DOES NOT harm aquatic species or wildlife. StormX is an end-of -pipe netting systems that can be used on pipe out falls, structures, and in channels to capture both floatables and non-floatables. StormX is not used in live streams where aquatic species and wildlife are present.Both products are proven internationally for over 20 years!Plastic recovery capacity: The BANDALONG LITTER TRAP will capture floating litter and debris 24/7 without mechanical assistance. It has unlimited capacity to capture floatables using our unique boom configuration with the trap without restriction of flow or harm to aquatic species or wildlife. Examples: Washington, DC first litter small Bandalong trap captured 6 tons the first year.  A large Bandalong in Mobile, AL 500 cubic yards the first year.NOTE: WITH THE UNIQUE DESIGN OF THE BANDALONG THE AMOUNTS COLLECTED DEPENDS ON THE AMOUNT OF TRASH FLOWING IN THE WATER THE CAPACITY IS UNLIMITED.STORMX capacity depends on the diameter of the  out flow pipe and the length of the net. All StormX installations need consideration for overflow/bypass options when nets are full of trash and debris.

name: The Blue Barriers: Collecting plastic waste in rivers before it reaches the sea
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Description: Since the beginning of the development of our technology, we have been in search of a simple solution.  To offer a permanent solution that can be scalable in so many different conditions, including where resources are limited simplicity represents high value. That is why we worked to keep the Blue Barriers simple to build, to be installed and to maintain. The structure is made by two parts: floating modules (made of recycled and recyclable polyethylene) and a supporting internal steel structure that makes the barriers rigid and able to resist to challenging river conditions thanks to three steel cable that cross the barriers. We consider several anchorage and mooring system options to adapt at the specific river; however, in case of rivers of a width below 50m we consider an anchorage above the river level, via steel cables. This allows avoiding creating any obstacle in the river flow. In wider rivers, we will choose anchorage in the river bad (deadweights or piles). Images that describes the Blue Barriers structure will be emailed to the address below. The area where the material will be collected will be along the riverbank in order to facilitate the removal of the material also in case of balky debris like logs. The collection area will be equipped by a steel grid that will screen the material, keep an active water flow that will drive the material toward the collection point and when specifically sized will allow the passage of biological components like fish eggs and other water organisms that might float.The system will be equipped with an automatic and manual opening system that will allow disengaging the barriers in case of emergency. The manual system provides a backup of the automatic one and the option of opening the barriers in case of forecasted exceptional floodings.The structure does not require energy to function ones installed. The only energy required will be for the collection of the debris with a mechanical arm with a crab or conveyor belt.The Blue Barriers have been developed with a modular design to fit any size of river, canal or water stream and for minimizing the cost of production, transportation and maintenance.Scientific studies report that a relevant portion of the plastic transported by the rivers accumulated below the water level in the first 50cm of the water column. That is why we designed the barriers in order to sink from 70 to 90 cm.Possible challenges will be the case of the transportation of abundant balky debris (logs, branches etc.). The Barriers structure will be sized to resist to such balky debris and the disengagement systems will be activated in case of exceptional quantities of wood transported.The simplicity of the structure, also, allows us to produce locally the barriers in the country where they will be installed, creating jobs locally and minimizing the environmental footprint of transportation.Plastic recovery capacity: The quantity of plastic collected will depend on the rivers where we will install our solution. Considering the estimate of plastic transported by the 20 most polluted rivers in the world (Lebreton et al, 2017), if we would install our barriers we would collect 1.19Mton of plastic per year.

name: The Great Bubble Barrier: A proven concept to reduce river plastics and an elegant bubbly solution to a worldwide problem.
remarks: The founders of The Great Bubble Barrier believe plastic waste can be caught before it reaches the oceans.Too much of the waste that our society produces ends up in the water, where it damages marine and human life. Sea turtles and fish get caught up in plastic, ships are obstructed in their paths, and micro plastics form a health hazard for the smallest to the largest organisms. Plastic soup is recognized as an international problem more and more, by both the public, municipalities, government and the European Union. The current solutions that stop waste in the rivers have two major drawbacks unfortunately; they block ship traffic and/or hinder fish movement.The Great Bubble Barrier team searched for an elegant solution that blocks waste in the river, but also allows the passage of fish and ships. They arrived at a very simple idea: a barrier of bubbles.The Great Bubble Barrier offers a solution for different problem-owners: it can help governments meet changing regulation on waste management in waterways, but also help cities fight plastic problems in their waters and help waterboards to save on their cleanups after high water. The three co-founders of the Great Bubble Barrier, Anne Marieke Eveleens, Francis Zoet and Saskia Studer, all have a big passion for sailing and nature. This is what inspired them to look for a fitting solution to the plastic soup, both fish & ship friendly.They have successfully run pilots in partnership with Deltares, Rijkswaterstaat & BAM / VandenHerik,  and are supported by sustainable & offshore organizations like Sustainable Young 100, Our Oceans Challenge, By The Ocean We Unite and the Plastic Soup Foundation. The Bubble Barrier intercepts 1 mm plastics in rivers and canals, and the team will further explore the possibilities and impact of our Bubble Barrier on microplastics coorperating with a research consortium formed by PWN (a drinking water company), KWR (research institut) and Hoogheemraadschap Hollands Noorderkwartier (HHNK - water management board). This consortium is starting a study to prevent microplastics from purified wastewater from flowing into surface water. With this, the consortium is taking a step towards clarifying the nature of the cause and reducing the occurrence of microplastics in surface water as they can pose a threat to people and the environment.The new Bubble Barrier installed in Wervershoof will give an insight into the physical effect of the Bubble Barrier on microplastics with a size of 0.5 mm to 0.02 mm.As 8 of the 10 most polluted rivers in the world, are located in Asia, the team want to bring The Great Bubble Barrier there as soon as possible and are hoping to start there in a couple of years from now. The first steps, and contacts have been made.

name: The Litter Gitter: Efficient and low impact litter collection device in rivers and shallow waters
remarks: Osprey Initiative, LLC is an environmental contractor providing tailored solutions to the global challenge of litter in our waters. Their mission is to bridge the gap between intent and action in the sustainability world by bringing and implementing realistic solutions to clients, partners and communities.Osprey is the owner of the Litter Gitter, a patented small stream litter collection device used to intercept floating litter from stormwater runoff. Intial tests indicate an 80+% success rate in preventing the downstream loss of floating litter. Osprey handles all aspects of installing and maintaining the Litter Gitter. Litter is separated from vegetative debris and recyclables are separated from the regular trash.As litter or debris floats down the waterway, it encounters the floating boom system, which is anchored in the embankment and attached to the Litter Gitter device. As litter hits these booms, the litter flows naturally into the trap where it waits until it is removed by the Osprey field crews for sorting, recycling, and data collection. The data from the captured litter provides a litter profile for each watershed that can be used to inform, develop, and implement source-targeted solutions. Data collection can be tailored to the specific requirements for a particular project, study, or grant. Quantities are recorded and results are reported on a quarterly basis for inclusion in MS4 reporting if needed.Osprey Initiative heavily emphasizes an approach that is low-tech, high-touch, and environmentally-friendly. They utilize kayaks, rubber waders, shallow draft mud boats, and a hands-on team, to remove harmful litter from the environment without negatively impacting the natural landscape and habitats. Osprey's goal is to manufacture the Litter Gitters using the aluminum collected by their river cleanup efforts. Another specialty service includes tactical cleanups of small and shallow waterways. Their methods range from walking in hip boots to canoes/kayaks to shallow draft mudboats to skiffs. Their cleanups are focused on causing a minimal impact to the natural environment and simple methods, even if they require some additional labor. They also provide safety and logistical support to community-based clean-ups.The company recently launched a product line that includes the Trash Stash, a wired cube or tower that securely stores litter you may find along your route. This product is designed to fit anywhere; secure them in the back of a truck bed, attached to a bike, or in a boat (motorized or not). They closed with a secured bungee cord, so it's always easy to throw litter right in, but secure enough to keep it there until it's time to empty. With every purchase of an Osprey product, 10% of the gross revenue goes right back into funding litter clean-ups.Whether they are deploying a Litter Gitter or conducting a systematic cleanup of a particular watershed, Osprey wants to leave an impact of environmental positivity and displays that passion in all facets of their company.  This solution is unique in that it aims to capture litter further upstream and closer to source points and can be affordably scaled to deploy several devices at key intercept locations on shallow waters and unique river bends. If there is a river or shallow body of water near you flooded with litter, contact the Osprey team about installing and managing a Litter Gitter! Currently cleaning up several rivers across the Southeast United States, this team continues to grow with new partnerships. As of April 2020, Osprey Initiative has 30 Litter Gitters in 11 watersheds, with more to come in the Summer of 2020. Learn more about where the Litter Gitter is cleaning by viewing the linked newsletters and website.

name: The Litterboom Project: River project to prevent plastic from reaching the oceans
remarks: The Litterboom Project is an initiative by Parley, that works on a solution to stop the flow of marine plastic waste.Approximately  90 percent of the plastic that causes marine pollution comes from river systems. Therefore the project aims to work on the preventive solutions by targeting the river systems instead of dealing with only oceans.The project stops the flow of plastic in the river systems and other local water sources using large, sealed, and robust pipes known as Litterbooms. The pipes are anchored across the river and it acts as a catchment for all surface-level plastics, which mostly consist of HDPE and PET. Each site consists of two to three Litterbooms. Keeping the storm and heavy rain in mind, the pipes are designed in a manner that under strain it only breaks from one side, preventing the loss of entire Litterboom when rivers rise. The preventive measure is set up strategically in a way that the team can collect most of the waste, sort, and send the plastic off for recycling. The project has successfully prevented 250 000 kgs of plastic from reaching the ocean in the past 2 years. This is done by engaging people from the local community. It has partnered with Parley, Tufbag, Wildlands, Astore Keymak, Fine Metals, and Cape Bulk Bags.The project is currently operating in five River systems around Durban, as well as 2 major river systems in Cape Town and aims to develop sustainable models that can be used throughout South Africa as well as Globally in the future.It benefits the communities, industries, government, and environment.

name: The Sea Cleaners: Deep water vessel capable of collecting large quantities of macro plastic waste from the sea
remarks: Sea Cleaners is an association that wants to tackle marine plastic pollution. They aim to remove the plastic out of water, in high density areas (coasts, estuaries) before it breaks down into microplastic, and the chemicals leach out, harming the marine life and people. They also want to decrease the large amounts of plastic waste in the oceans.The boat that will be used is called Manta, as it draws its inspiration from the mantis, and its large mouth. The Manta is meant for operations in open sea. It will be a floating factory that collects, sorts, compacts and stores plastic waste. Mantas will have three collecting treadmills between the hulls of the ship to scoop up big quantities of plastics. By compacting the waste, the Manta will be able to accommodate large quantities of waste and is estimated to hold 250 tons of waste. This will then be carried back to land and forwarded to relevant recycling centers. Besides cleaning the oceans, this project aims to conduct scientific observation, and involve itself in prevention of pollution, in education and achieving a circular economy.The MANTA is based on the most advanced technologies in terms of clean energy, design, naval architecture, waste collection and treatment at sea. However, this is still work in progress, and they want more partners who will get involved and help in improving the design of the boat. The company is also looking for technical and financial partners to take the project forward. Feasibility studies have been carried out for eighteen months and a model ship is nearly ready.Sea Cleaners was founded in 2016 by Yvan Bourgnon, a French Swiss explorer, and is based in France. Sea Cleaners work has already won it approval from The Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation who are interested in environment protection.

name: Thomsea
remarks: Description: C TO SEA provide some antipollution trawl net made and patented by THOMSEA to fight against all the floating marine pollution. With this very efficient tool, it is possible to collect plastic waste, hydrocarbon, macro waste, pelagic seaweed, debris... It exists a lot of advantage to use these trawls nets. One of best reasons is its social role with local fishermen. Indeed, we recommand to use the local fishermen knowledge fo using ours trawls nets. Fishermen are always happy to help and save their marine environment. Second reason, these tools are very easy and very quickly to implement. For example, we just need one boat (Like a zodiac with 50 hp) and 2 persons to use the T2 THOMSEA trawl. However, the T2 are be abble to collect 2 tons of hydrocarbon or 500 kg of plastic waste.Other reason and proof of effectiveness, our French navy use ours trawls nets to fight against oils spills for a lot of years. Plastic recovery capacity: For T1 : 40 to 50 kg (85 or 110 lbs)For T2 : about 500 kg to 1 ton of plastic waste (Depending of plastic size). total capacity : 2 tonsFor T8 : about 2 or 3 tons of plastic waste (Depending of plastic size). Total capacity : 8 tons

name: Trash booms: Floating barriers that stop waste from entering the oceans
remarks: Plastic Fischer, a Germany-based environmental start-up has developed TrashBooms to intercept floating waste such as plastic from rivers.Nearly 80% of the plastic that ends up in the ocean comes from rivers. Plastic Fischers TrashBooms, which are essentially floating barriers, collect plastic in rivers before it enters the oceans.  The barriers made from locally available materials such as PVC pipes, stainless steel, and galvanized steel wire mesh. Plastic Fischer decided to publish the construction manual open source on their hompage. It is important to ensure a frequent pickup to prevent the system from overloading. The TrashBooms were tested in the worlds most polluted river, the Citarum River in Bandung, Indonesia. Plastic Fischer won the GreenTech Challenge Lisbon in June 2019, became Country Champion Indonesia at the GAIA Impact challenge Jakarta in December 2019, and won the Circular Challenge France in December 2020.Plastic Fischer develops various technologies apart from these TrashBooms that are suitable for any given river condition and is offering companies to become Plastic Neutral by paying the company for their collection operations in India, Indonesia, and Vietnam.

name: Trash Wheel
remarks: Description: Storm sewers and feeder streams carry trash-laden runoff to rivers that flow to harbors, bays, and oceans. The Trash Wheel harnesses renewable energy to collect and remove trash and debris from a flowing waterway. Containment booms funnel the floating trash and debris to a conveyor.  A waterwheel provides mechanical power to the conveyor using energy from the river current and solar powered pumps.  The trash is lifted by the conveyor and deposited into a dumpster. The conveyor and waterwheel are mounted on a floating platform that is held in place by pilings.  The dumpster is located on a separate barge, which is pushed by a service vessel to a transfer point for disposal.  A covering structure over the conveyor and dumpster prevents trash from being blown by the wind, protects the equipment, and provides a support structure for the photovoltaic panels. The covering structure is adapted to the specific location to optimize the power generation by the solar panels.  The machine also features an internet based remote control and monitoring system which uses cameras to monitor the trash flow and the dumpster level as well as web based controls which allow the pumps to be turned on or off from a smart phone or a computer from anywhere the internet is available.  Our flagship model in Baltimore collects trash and debris from the Jones Falls River, the largest tributary to the citys Inner Harbor.  Its floating platform is 50 long by 24 wide and constructed of quarter inch epoxy coated steel.  The waterwheel is 14 in diameter and constructed of precision cut galvanized steel.  The 36 long conveyor is submerged to a depth of 2 feet at the upstream end; and fills a 15-18 cubic yard roll-off dumpster.  The solar power is generated from a 3 kilowatt array and powers 9 pumps capable of moving more than 25,000 gallons per hour.  Clearwater Mills also offers both larger and smaller models to fit a wide variety of waterways.  Demonstrated Results:On demand collection of floating trash and debris90% capture rateCapable of unattended remote operationUses renewable power sourcesDoes not harm aquatic wildlifeProvides an opportunity for measurement and analysis of storm water pollutants and upstream mitigation effortsProvides an opportunity for educating the public about the problem of plastic pollution and inspires people to become part of the solutionAn attractive means for addressing an unsightly problemLow operating costsDoes not require specialty service equipment or disposable refuse nets or other containersHigh quality construction for reliability and durabilityPerformance:The first Baltimore Trash Wheel was installed in May of 2014 and has removed approximately 200 tons of trash and debris a year, including more than 45 tons from a single storm event.  It is capable of filling an 18 cubic yard dumpster in less than 2 hours and can remove more than 50,000 pounds of solid waste per day.  The profound effect it has had on the harbor has been noted by nearly everyone who lives, works, or recreates there.  This success has led to three more Trash Wheels for Baltimore.Plastic recovery capacity: Trash Wheels have the capacity to capture and remove 50,000 lbs of trash and debris/day. The percentage of plastics depends on the characteristics of the watershed (urban and/or rural0 and ranges from 20 to 80 percent.

name: Waste Free Oceans
remarks: Description: Waste Free Oceans (WFO) collects and transforms ocean plastic into new, innovative products. They partner with recyclers, converters and brand owners to make optimal use of available resources and raise awareness on the issue of ocean plastic. Based in Brussels, they also operate in the Americas, Asia and Turkey & MEA. WFO acquired innovative, yet simple, Trash Catchers, which can remove between 2 and 8 tonnes of floating marine debris per journey. They offer a locally implementable solution to marine litter: attaching nets to fishing boats. The aim is to lease them to businesses and NGOs in areas of waste accumulation. WFO collaborates with companies to create products from the recycled material, making optimal use of available plastic resources. Connecting brands to their trusted network of plastic recyclers and converters, WFO builds the bridge in transforming marine litter into new, sustainable products. WFO lobbies stakeholders at all levels to raise awareness about the issue of marine litter and implements projects to motivate behaviour change. They welcome participation in beach clean-ups or fundraisers. In 2013, WFO successfully lobbied EU policy makers to secure subsidies from the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) for fishermen to be remunerated for performing marine clean-ups. With the growing global call to action to address the issue of marine litter, WFO feels that they are ideally placed to offer practical answers: their strong connections within the European plastics and recycling industries and extensive experience in recovering, recycling and reusing marine plastics allow them to contribute to cleaner waters. Since the beginning of 2019, ten new sponsors have joined forces with Waste Free Oceans, in order to protect the worlds oceans and waterways. These include Dow, proWIN, Persan, Jansy, Iglo, Keter, Stop the Water while using me!, Fapil, Retal, and Airbus. Plastic recovery capacity: Between 2 and 8 tonnes of marine litter can be collected per journey.

name: WasteShark
remarks: Description: The WasteShark™ eats plastics and other litter; detects chemicals in the water and extracts alien and pest vegetation. The plastic that is collected is floating material. The patented design makes it one of the most technologically advanced waste-management tools in the world. Equally effective in ports, marinas, rural waterways and urban environments, the WasteShark leaves zero carbon footprint while it works. Modelled on planet Earths biggest fish, the Whale Shark, our drones are designed to be efficient, long-lived, non-threatening and unobtrusive.The DataShark™ is a learning machine, designed for round-the clock water analysis. It scans and monitors the environment, sending data back to central command and communicating with other drones in the water continually collecting data about the marine environment.Plastic recovery capacity: 500 kg / 8 hrs

name: Ellipsis: Machine learning and aerial imagery to identify, map, and track plastic waste
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Ellipsis Earth has developed a unique technology to detect, map, and track plastic waste globally via machine learning algorithms and high tech imagery. Globally, plastic waste is an area of growing concern due to its harmful effects on the environment and all living beings. While 10 million tonnes of plastic waste finds its way into our oceans annually, there is still 99% of plastic waste that is unaccounted for, with no reliable data available on where this plastic waste eventually ends up. Lack of clear data on this plastic waste hinders our ability to identify it for recycling or proper disposal, thereby increasing the harmful impact it has on our environment.Ellipsis Earths technology can not only identify plastic waste around the world, but also classify it into different categories such as bottles, containers, sheets, etc. This data can eventually be used by governments and companies to identify plastic accumulation areas and collect the waste for recycling or safe disposal.The data can also be used to inform and educate the public on how and where plastic waste accumulates so that corrective measures can be taken and environment-friendly initiatives can be planned.Ellipsis does this by capturing video and stills from around the world using any source, be it drones, submarines, satellites, or CCTV, and feeding the visuals into its proprietary identification platform. If needed, it can even deploy a drone from its network of over 500 drones to capture images and videos of client sites.All the images are stitched together into a master image for geospatial mapping. The Ellipsis software, through its custom machine learning, can identify plastic with 93% accuracy and 95% certainty. It then classifies the plastic into different categories. The algorithm can also be tailored to identify different types of plastic, brands, and local items.Based on the plastic found in that particular area, it also creates heat maps which can be updated over time. The collected data is then used to prepare content to create awareness about plastic wastage.Buoyed by its success, Ellipsis is launching a mobile app in 2020 for the public. Some of the partners with whom Ellipsis works are National Geographic, Marevivo, BAT, Encounter Edu, and British Science Association, among others.NGOs, government organisations, companies working in the field of plastic management and wastage are the potential clients for Ellipsis Earth.

name: Fishing for Litter: Ocean cleaning project that involves fishermen who collect debris during fishing activities
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: KIMO International works with fishermen to clean the seas, by providing them with large bags to collect litter, which is then recycled or disposed.Marine pollution is one of the biggest environmental concerns worldwide. Not only does it add to the growing pollution levels across the world, but also endangers marine and human lives, who are dependent on oceans for their living. Marine pollution also affects the livelihood of fishermen, through reduced fishing opportunities.The Fishing for Litter project was initiated by KIMO International at a single port in the Netherlands, and it has grown and spread across Europe. European Organisations such as OSPAR have endorsed the program and encourages its 15 member countries to take part in it actively, as a part of its Regional Action Plan against marine litter.The Fishing for Litter team provides fishing vessels with large bags to collect plastics and other debris from the oceans, which gathers in their nets during their fishing activities.When the fishing boats return to port, they offload the collected waste to Fishing for Litter volunteers who either recycle the waste or dispose it suitably.The goal of the Fishing for Litter team is to promote cleaner seas, cleaner beaches, and a better marine environment for all marine lives and humans.More than 1,000 fishing vessels are now involved in this project from 8 countries across Europe and 450 tonnes of plastic and other waste was recovered from the oceans in 2016-17.Encouraged by the response of this initiative, the EU has revised its Port Reception Facilities Directive to make a special provision and space for the Fishing for Litter project. This will encourage more ports and ships to be a part of this project.All ports and shipping vessels that would like the oceans and seas to be cleaner can be a part of this initiative.

name: Ho'ola One: A power tool that collects the small waste accumulated on the Kam ilo beach
remarks: Ho'ola one works towards removing microplastics from the environment of the beach. Twelve engineering students at the University of Sherbrooke in Quebec built a machine for the organization that isolates plastic pieces from the sandy beaches. For several years, the plastic waste that ends on Kamilo Beach has been breaking down into increasingly fine particles. Through the years the Hawai'i Wildlife Fund has managed to dump the bulky debris, but it's the small stuff left behind buried in the sand, that's the remaining problem. Animals confuse plastic particles with insects or other living organisms and ingest them. Plastic therefore enters the food chain and poisons it. The Ho'ola One project team aims to help combat this problem.At University of Sherbrooke, twelve mechanical engineering students have been devoted to this major design project for the last two years of their degree. Leatherman, an aquatic biologist and President of the Hawai'i Wildlife Fund, believes the 'Ho'ola One' - a sand like vacuum designed by Canadian engineering students, is the solution. The machine has a big vacuum that collects the mix of sand and plastics, once the sand is dropped into a water tank, the sand sinks and the plastic floats. The machine works by separating the plastic parts from sand using the density of the diverse components. The plastic pieces are often too small to be handpicked, however with the help of the machine the minute plastic particles are picked.The device has removed roughly 230-pounds of micro-plastics at Kamilo Point (in Hawaï) in a matter of days.

name: Ocean Polymers: Building a plastic recycling plant in the ocean to convert plastic into power.
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Ocean Polymers is committed to turning plastic waste into a valuable resource. The startup is constructing a tanker, named OP3 with a gasification system that has the capacity of processing 200 tons of plastic and waste per day thanks to its onboard machinery which recycles plastic found in the ocean and converts it into hydrogen to power the station. The firm has been working with a team from Imperial College London on the project for the past six years, and it hopes to get up and running in the second half of 2019. During the recycling process on the ship, valuable products such as hydrogen, synthetic gases, building materials and substrates will be created. Their systems will not only remove plastics which are harmful to marine wildlife and enter the food chain but it is self-funding when operating, as a result of the valuable bi-products created.The project will involve smaller boats traveling short distances to take rubbish back to the main ship. Ocean Polymers has secured the patent pending status that has been granted by the US Patent Office on 14th May 2019.  They are in the process of securing intellectual property rights and developing a business plan.

name: OceanCycle: Certification for ocean-bound plastics
remarks: Description: Currently our system is diverting over 1,500 MT of plastic per month from our oceans and this material is actually being used. Products range from packaging to textiles to engineering grade resins. Materials are being used in Europe, the US, and Asia. Our systems approach is deigned for scale and cost and has the ability to triple capacity right away. Available materials are PET, PP, and PEPlastic recovery capacity: Metric tons. Currently, we divert about 1,500 MT per month. We could scale to 5,000 within 1-2 months and 10,000 within 4-5 months (COVID travel dependent).

name: Planet Patrol App: Paddleboarding for a cause: to rid our waterways of plastic pollution
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: Planet Patrol is a charity with an aim to rid the inland waterways of intense plastic pollution, using the collaborative power of community action coupled with the use of disruptive technology to acquire data for research in developing sustainable alternatives.Plastic pollution is becoming an increasingly critical crisis, upsetting food chains and disrupting entire ecosystems. By 2050, the weight of plastic dumped in the ocean is projected to be twice the weight of all the fish and marine life living in it. Single-use plastic is a major source of the plastic crisis, with a mere 1% of single-use plastic bags being returned for recycling and with an average life cycle of just 12 minutes. Inland waterways are usually the origin for dumping waste plastic, which travels and find their way into the oceans. Planet Patrol launched to tackle this environmental catastrophe by organising community-driven clean-ups and collecting data on plastic pollution data using the Planet Patrol App. Every clean-up brings communities together, where waste is seen, photographed, shared on the app and cleared away; serving an equivocal purpose of helping the environment and acquisition of data. The data collected is used for scientific research into waste that escapes into nature, and helps stop the pollution at the first point of contact with the environment. The Planet Patrol app is a real-world tool that provides a platform for data collection and sharing along with community interaction; done by combining the power of citizen science and scientific analysis. The app will enable Planet Patrol to record and analyze data to conduct the world's largest survey of inland plastic pollution, with the River Thames in London alone carrying 18 tonnes of plastic. The users are required to categorize each piece by type and brand before uploading the photos. The app also aids in building a worldwide community of environmentally aware individuals, actively working towards eliminating plastic from our waterways through a collaborative effort. Nearly 300,000 pieces of plastic have been logged from over 80 countries using the #PlanetPatrol App, having intercepted 440 tonnes of plastic waste from inland waterways; that is equivalent to 15 million water bottles. They also organise corporate clean-ups and workshops to accelerate the process of eliminating single-use plastics and embed sustainability in workplaces.

name: Plastic Odyssey: The Expedition Around The World To Fight Against Plastic Pollution
remarks: Plastic Odyssey is a non-profit organization that aims to fight against plastic pollution by acting at the source: ashore. Their vision? Build a global network of local initiatives. Their ambition? Clean up the past and build the future!How? By encouraging social entrepreneurship at the local level, developing low-tech and open source technologies, and stimulating social engagement to empower local communities.Their means? A 40 meters laboratory vessel, ambassador for the reduction and recycling of plastic waste that conceives, creates and develops simple solutions accessible to all, to reduce plastic pollution in the Ocean. Their ship will leave in early 2021 for a 3-year expedition across 3 continents, and over 30 cities, to uncover and share solutions.The vessel, which embodies a real life-size demonstration platform to assess and promote tomorrows solutions, will circumnavigate along the worlds most polluted coasts to reconcile global challenges with local development. Onboard will be displayed:Low-tech and open source technologies to recycle plastic wasteA mobile nomadic village to share knowledge and action tools with the remotestTo give you a little more perspective on the journey of their project, here are their stopovers:2021: Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria, Morocco, Senegal, Guinea, Brazil, Haiti, Costa Rica, Ecuador2022: Peru, Polynesia, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia2023: Thailand, Myanmar, India, Sri Lanka, Maldives, Madagascar, Mozambique, South Africa, Angola, Ivory Coast. You can find out more about their stopovers HERE.  Their sponsors:Main partner: LOccitane en ProvenceOfficial partners: Crédit Agricole, Clarins, MatmutSocial partners: Enowe, BiodermaPatrons: Veolia, Procapital, Ponant: Fondation Océans Pôles-Peuples, Octopus Invest, PaxArctica, FeelingoTechnical partners: Setec, The Dung Beetle Project, Trivéo, InsaValor, Bee EngineeringMedia Partners: Springwise, Bonne Pioche, RFIOfficial suppliers and service providers: Marlink, Stephenson Hardwood, Smart Sailors, Sofresid, Latham WatkinsAre you are representative of a company, an association, or an institution, and wish to commit yourself to their project? Become a partner of the project! They need you to make this adventure possible and build a world free of plastic in the Ocean.

name: Safegear: Partnership to fight ghost gear
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
geo_coverage: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland
remarks: The Blue Marine Foundation (BLUE) is a charity dedicated to creating marine reserves and establishing sustainable models of fishing. Blue's aim is to put 10% of the worlds oceans under protection by 2020 and 30% by 2030. They also work to establish sustainable fisheries so fish stocks can begin to recover.Over-fishing represents a major food security issue and has devastating consequences for the fragile biodiversity of our planet. Around 90% of global fish stocks are fully or over-exploited and around 90% of large fish are gone. The consequences are far-reaching, not only for the future of food for a growing global population, but because healthy oceans absorb half the CO2 we produce, this led them come up with The Blue Marine Foundation.Every year, an estimated 640,000 tons of fishing gear is lost in the oceans around the world. Safegear offers a simple solution to stop this plastic pollution.Beacons are being designed to fit onto existing fishing gear markers that normally comprise of a float, bamboo pole, and flag. It allows fishing vessels to inexpensively monitor their gear at sea, receive alerts if the gear starts to move, and contact vessels in the area. If gear is lost due to towing or bad weather, the beacon allows the fishing vessel to track the gear and recover it.These electronic beacons will also allow the fishing gear markers to be viewed on the bridge, wheelhouse and cockpit plotters of other marine traffic so they can avoid the hazard. Existing markers are almost impossible to see at night and often difficult in daylight.The Blue Marine Foundation has won various awards and recognitions -In 2014 BLUE won NGO of the Year in the PEA (People Environment Achievement) Awards in recognition that it was getting results where they matter most. In 2015 BLUE won four PEA Awards as part of the GB Oceans Coalition including Overall Champion.

name: SeaChange: Converting ocean plastics to inert, non-toxic glass safe for marine life
remarks: SeaChange is seeking to solve the marine plastics problem and create an end game for ocean plastics.Only 9% of the 400 million tons of plastic produced globally each year is recycled. Much of that unrecycled plastic ends up in oceans with approximately one dump truck load of plastic is put into the ocean every minute. When exposed to the sun, these plastics can degrade into harmful microplastics. SeaChange wants to act before this can happen and stop the pollution cycle by removing plastics from the waste stream.Using a plasma enhanced melter (PEM), SeaChange wants to collect ocean plastics and convert them into a non-toxic, inert glass that is safe for humans and marine life. The PEM breaks down the molecular structure of plastics at temperatures up to 18,000°F. The process converts 5 tons of plastic a day into clean syngas and glass. The syngas can be used for fuel. SeaChange plans on utilizing the PEM technology on ships that can be deployed in areas with a large amount of plastic waste.Phase 1 of their mission is focused on deploying SeaChange ships in the Indonesian archipelago where 1.42 million tons of plastic leak into the ocean every year. SeaChange utilizes InEnTec's PEM system.

name: 100% Recyclable Pouch
Algae Bioplastic
Ashored: Innovations for profitable and sustainable ocean harvests
remarks: Ashored develops sustainability-enabling technologies for the commercial fishing industry. Ashored is currently developing a rope on-command (ROC) fishing system to minimize the risk of whale entanglements and trap loss/damage, while allowing fishers to fish in zones closed to fixed fishing gear. Marine animal entanglements and ghost fishing are creating huge issues in oceans. Entanglements are the leading cause of death for North Atlantic Right Whales and 83% of the population has visible scars from fishing gear entanglement. To remedy this, Ashored is developing new fishing systems to allow fishing to continue while creating safer conditions for whales.Ashoreds underwater buoy/rope releases work with existing lobster/crab traps/trawl lines and allow for said gear to be activated via acoustics (or a backup timer) to the surface. Once the buoy and connecting rope rise to the surface, fishermen can use existing onboard equipment and processes to retrieve the gear and prepare it for redeployment. Ashoreds ROC fishing systems include a rope containment and release module (MOBI) that also uses sensors to collect and transmit data to an onboard gear tracking system (ATLAS). ATLAS consists of Ashoreds ATLAS+ software and smart tagging to reduce gear loss and allow fishers to automate the tracking of gear and logging of catch information.

name: Bionic Yarn: Recycled Plastic Fabric Yarn
remarks: BIONIC® is a mission-driven material engineering company, addressing ocean plastic pollution in marine and coastal environments. Their vision is to unite industry leading brands to substantially and measurably reduce ocean plastic.BIONIC engineers fully traceable high-grade textiles and polymers made with coastal and marine plastic. Starting in Costa Rica's Nicoya Peninsula, they helped establish a collection and recovery system that allowed them to have raw materials they could use to create their products.The product line consists of three yarns: HLX®, DPX® and FLX™, each of which serves different functions and are highly adaptable to suit a wide range of applications, and multiple variations of polymer resin.In 2010, after engaging with his streetwear brand BBC/Ice Cream, Grammy award winning artist and producer Pharrell Williams became the companys third partner. In 2016 BIONIC joined forces with Waterkeeper Alliance, Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.s global environmental not for profit.The companys early focus on forward-thinking fashion, including everything from jeans and suits to snowboarding jackets and haute couture dresses, earned high-profile collaborations with brands like Timberland, Burton, G-Star, ONeill, H&M and Chanel and appealed to people who didnt want to forsake looking good for feeling good.

name: Biogreen
Norton Point: Turning recovered ocean plastic into sunglasses
remarks: Norton Point is an eyewear brand based on the island of Martha's Vineyard, MA and was founded in 2015 with a goal to make sustainable sunglasses from ocean plastic and plant based materials.Norton Point's team believe that the 8 million metric tons of plastic flowing into our oceans is one of our planet's greatest environmental challenges, and they have chosen to become part of the solution.The company has developed the first line of eyewear made from recovered high-density-polyethylene (HDPE) ocean plastics. For every product sold Norton Point is committing to clean-up one pound of plastic from the ocean. The team has also chosen to give back 5% of net profits to global clean-up, education, and remediation practices. Getting started was no easy task. Luckily they had the right past work and life experiences to navigate the various obstacles and attract key partners like The Plastic Bank. Finding ocean plastic and securing high-quality manufacturers was complicated. But they were able to find partners who were willing to take a risk on their dream and help them figure out how to make sunglasses from recovered ocean plastic.

name: rePurpose: Global community of conscious consumers, workplaces, and brands going #PlasticNeutral by empowering waste workers worldwide
remarks: Winners of UPenn President's 2018 Engagement Prize and UC Berkeley's 2019 Global Social Ventures Competition, rePurpose helps conscious consumers, genuine workplaces, and forward-thinking brands worldwide go PlasticNeutral by measuring, offsetting, and reducing their unique footprint.rePurpose is a web platform that enables individual consumers worldwide go PlasticNeutral in three steps: Measure your plastic footprint through our 3-minute interactive calculator Offset your unique footprint by contributing $3-5 per month to a vetted recycling social enterprise in India who will recycle an equivalent amount of plastic waste otherwise landfilled or burnedReduce your impact on our planet through ConsciousLiving tips & tricks, uniquely curated for you based on your consumption patternsThey have also developed multiple first-of-its-kind solutions for pioneering corporates to take action on plastic pollution: #PlasticNeutral workplaces: rePurpose helps employee-centric organizations (e.g. consultancies, finance, technology) measure their footprint with the startup's proprietary tools, offset their emissions through vetted waste management enterprises in India, and engage their staff on green living through a personalized ConsciousLiving guide curated based on their individual footprints.  Everyday PlasticNeutral: any brand/retailer offering products containing plastic can add a simple tick-box at the point of checkout for their environmentally conscious customers to take easy climate action & add no more than $0.5 to neutralize the unique plastic footprint of their purchase that day. Individualized solutions: their modular offerings & on-the-ground operations enable them to provide individual components of their holistic solutions, such as a green living employee engagement platform, customized offsets for certain brands within the broader portfolio, and providing ethically sourced recycled plastic from India to incorporate into products.

name: RePurpose Global
The 3R Initiative: Credit-based market system to encourage plastic recycling and recovery
remarks: To catalyse zero plastic waste leadership, the 3R Initiative (3RI) is developing a market-based approach that will scale up recovery and recycling activities and increase accountability for plastic waste reduction efforts around the world. The 3RI supports a market for plastic credits which will transparently and sustainably increase the value of plastic and beverage carton waste, and incentivize new activities that support the circular economy. The 3RI supports the following three elements:The Guidelines for Corporate Plastic Stewardship facilitate corporate plastic footprint assessment and communication of credible mitigation actions, enabling companies to meet leadership commitments. The Guidelines, which the 3RI developed in coordination with South Pole (a 3RI member), EA and Quantis, share principles of credible corporate plastic stewardship programs, key metrics for accounting for plastic footprint and leakage, guidance for the appropriate implementation of a range of plastic waste mitigation activities, and leadership claims related to plastic waste and circularity.     The Plastic Waste Reduction Standard (Plastic Standard) is an efficient and powerful means of supporting activities that verifiably reduce plastic in the environment anywhere in the world. The Plastic Standard, developed by Verra with the support of the 3R Initiative, establishes consistent accounting and verification processes for plastic waste collection and/or recycling activities and enables the issuance of credits for plastic collected and recycled above baseline rates. The independently-audited Plastic Standard includes significant social and environmental safeguards.     The Circular Action Hub: a platform that connects local waste management projects and activities with companies and investors willing to support, accelerate and strengthen a more effective and socially-responsible circular economy. The Circular Action Hub, developed and managed by BVRio, aims to create demand, price discovery and liquidity for 3R Initiative pilots and Plastic Credits certified to the Plastic Waste Reduction Standard. It promotes a wide range of activities and funding pathways, including sponsorship, investment, or credit purchase.
